subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 15th August (vide page 11604), on motion by Senator, Russell -
That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: . - In addressing myself to this Bill, I recognise that it is a very important measure, and one that directly affects our primary producers. I am not altogether satisfied with the manner in which it was introduced, or with the matter brought before us by the Minister when he was moving the second reading. He said there are practically five Bills in one, which means that five very important industries are dealt with, in one measure. As the new standing order limits honorable senators to sixty minutes in which to deliver a second-reading speech, we have only twelve minutes in which to deal with each of the five huge industries concerned. I am quite unable to condense my remarks and at the same time deal fully with the provisions of the Bill. I am absolutely at a loss to intelligently discuss questions of such magnitude in the limited time at my disposal.
- If you say anything worth listening to, your time may be extended.

- Whether my remarks are interesting or not shall not be decided by a vote of the Senate. The offer of an extension of time by Senator Earle and the party of which he is a member, and which has forced us to deal with the Bill under the conditions to which I have referred, will not receive my favorable consideration. I am not complaining of the new standing order, as all through life it has been my endeavour to adapt myself to new circumstances, and make the best of new conditions.

speech.para: The Wheat Pool was brought into existence by the Hughes Government, to assist the producers of Australia. The Hughes Government has changed its personnel so frequently that I am doubtful as to which Government I am referring to. I was a member of the Fisher Government during 1914-15, and of a Hughes Government during 1915-16, and I believe it was during the latter period that the Government brought the Wheat Pool into existence. The predominant reason for its establishment was scarcity of freight, and the possibility of vessels coming to our shores being seriously reduced in number, with the result that the farmers would be left with huge stocks of wheat on hand. In those days, when we had good government, Providence blessed us with good seasons; and the Wheat Pool was established to secure to the farmer what was then considered a fair price for his produce, which was at that time abundant. We had to face some troubles in forming such a huge Pool, and in financing it. I desire to give full credit to the financial institutions of the country, the private banking concerns. When they realized the enormous proportions of this new project they did not fail to appreciate that it might eventually interfere with their interests, yet they met us in a spirit which, permitted us to finance it But when it was discovered that our first overdraft would amount to about £8,000,000, and when arrangements to cope with that overdraft were being made, the financial concerns, realizing that we were short of the necessary money by some millions sterling, were quite prepared to take a perfectly legitimate advantage of the situation, and to increase their rate of interest. However, the Commonwealth Government arranged otherwise.

talk.start.para: - No !

- I am speaking of what I know, and I do not desire to be interrupted by the Minister. Thanks to the fact that the Commonwealth Government has a banking institution of its own behind it, the rate of interest was kept at the original mark. These matters are well worth considering at a time when the Federal Parliament is dealing with a proposal to extend the operations of the various Pools. Senator Russell claims that the continuation of the Wheat Pools is not desired for any reason except that it is necessary that the authorities concerned shall be given sufficient time to complete contracts already entered into. If the wheat scheme has proved a huge success, so far as the primary producers are concerned; if, indeed, it has not merely given them a vast sum of money, but has actually and literally saved them, why should the Government, which claims to be the special and peculiar representative of the primary producer, make no effort to secure an extension of the Wheat Pools beyond the very short period set forth in the Bill?

speech.para: So far as my objection to this measure is concerned it will be based chiefly upon the fact that the Pools are not to be continued for all time for the benefit of primary producers, but are to be continued only for the assistance of big interests. The smaller interests, and the whole community in relation to the cost of living, are to be ignored. The Government has entered into no contracts to alter the conditions bearing down upon the rank and file of working men to-day; the latter are neglected, and' it is merely the big interests which are to be looked after in the Bill. I am quite aware, of course, that the Government has no constitutional power to deal with the other interests just indicated. But the Government could very quickly and easily have secured the necessary power. As soon as the armistice was signed, or at any period during the peace negotiations, the Government, if it had truly desired to conserve the best interests of the community, could have called Parliament together, and it could have gone to the people for the necessary power to enable it to adequately meet the needs of the community in relation to the cost of living. And, by the date on which this present measure was introduced, those necessary powers could have been conferred. However, that course of action was not taken.

Senator Russell seemed to think that because the Wheat Pools have showed a profit on the whole series of transactions they may be said to be a huge success. It evidently gives him satisfaction to think that all the criticisms levelled at himself during the period of his Ministerial control may be said to have been swept aside because there is a sum on the right side of the ledger. Senator Russell holds the opinion that, no matter what has been said regarding bad management, ineptitude, and lack of business foresight, the Wheat Pools have proved a success, because there is a credit 'balance, and there is still unsold wheat on hand. I cannot understand that method of reasoning. I fail to see why, when the Minister was describing the success of the wheat scheme as a whole, he could not supply all the facts indicating the full extent of its success. It is not merely that the £18,000,000 overdraft has been met, and that there are some millions of bushels of wheat still in hand. The Minister was very vague with respect to the stocks still in hand. The wheat in the stacks is represented, on paper, as being equal to the quantity of wheat delivered into the stacks. But mice and Tats and weevils have destroyed great stocks. In addition to those factors there is the possibility that the total shown on paper has never actually reached the stacks. We are living in a business community. My idea of the business methods of the community is that those methods aim entirely at making money anyhow - honestly or otherwise. The quantity of wheat shown in the books of the Wheat Board as having been delivered into the stacks may never have actually reached the stacks.

talk.start.para: - That is fraud, not business.

- Exactly ! That is a dishonest business method, and since I have not the absolute proofs, nor - if I possessed them - the time to prove cases of fraud, I shall leave that phase of the subject to 'be dealt with when the full history of the Wheat Pools come3 to be written.
- I am not responsible for the management of the stacks.
- Hear, hear !
- I do not care who is responsible; but, if I had my way, a Minister in the Commonwealth Government would be responsible for each one of the Pools in existence.

speech.para: The Government of which I was a member entered into arrangements with the various wheat States, but if the Commonwealth Constitution had permitted us to conduct the whole business alone, the scheme would have proved much more effective and efficient than the present system of divided control. A Minister of the Crown in New South Wales recently made certain grave charges before a Royal Commission, which charges did not amount to much, after all, except that a certain individual was shown to have been given a contract involving over £500,000 in money, without being required to put up one shilling by way of deposit. Senator Russell may say that the Commonwealth Government is not in any way responsible for that, and that it is purely a

State matter. The Commonwealth Government cannot refuse to share its responsibility for unwise business transactions of that kind. Here was a deal which enabled one man to secure the use of some £500,000 worth of Commonwealth and State property; he was given the sole right to exploit the Eastern markets in relation to that property-

talk.start.para: - It belongs to the farmers.
- What was done was dishonest to the farmers.

speech.para: But, notwithstanding the ravages of mice and weevil, and the waste due to inefficient management, the farmer is still in a much better position under the wheat scheme than he would have been without it; that is to say, had his produce been subject to the ravages of private enterprise in connexion with commissions when wheat was cheap. One very prominent man connected with the wheat trade has assured me that the losses sustained on account of the ravages of weevil and mice are nothing as compared with the losses sustained on account of the commission which private buyers used to get. If that be so - and I am inclined to think that it is a fact - and if a better method of handling our primary products is within reach, the Commonwealth Government, as representing the farmers and the people of Australia, should not withhold their hands for a single day. They should unquestionably adopt that improved method. It is a sad reflection upon the people of Australia, that this Parliament does not possess the power to do this at the present time. Under the War Precautions Act, which has been subjected to a good deal of criticism from time to time, the Government intrusted with the conduct of the war was vested with power to do whatever it willed to do. But if that Statute had not been enacted it would still have been the inherent power of any Government - when the nation was either threatened with war, or was actually at war - to do whatever they deemed it necessary to do for the protection of this country. In other words, the Executive Government of Australia could, in time of war, without the aid of the War Precautions Act, have done all that it did under that Statute.

Our constitutional powers in this connexion were first called into question when the Commonwea.th Government fixed the price of bread. Certain business persons were not content to allow us to insure that the people should obtain bread at a reasonable price. To them it did not matter that our granaries were overflowing, or that we had been blessed bv Providence with the most bountiful seasons. Immediately the Government fixed the price of bread, certain persons engaged in that industry contested the validity of our powers. The case soon after came before the High Court, but it was not until the 13th May, 1916, that the decision of that tribunal was forthcoming. The whole of the delay experienced was due to the fact that our Constitution was then in exactly the condition in which we find it to-day. The decision of the High Court was' practically that the question whether it was necessary to fix the price of bread in order to enable us to conduct the war successfully was one for the Executive alone to determine. If the Cabinet said that it was necessary to do so, it had' a right to fix the price. That decision on the part of the highest legal tribunal in this country confirmed the opinion we had previously entertained. Subsequently the operations of government in this connexion were vastly extended.

Coming back to the Wheat Pool, I unhesitatingly affirm that during the period it has been in existence much valuable experience has been gained. For example, we have learned how to conserve the wheat during good seasons with as little damage as possible. As the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator Russell) has pointed out, we were confronted, shortly after the establishment of the Pool, with a mice plague of unparalleled magnitude, owing to the huge storage of wheat which had been effected in various portions of this country. But an easy method for coping with this pest, and thus keeping the stacks free of it, was very soon discovered. What has since happened in regard to our wheat? Senator Russell did not tell us what he expected the whole profit of the Pool to be, He has withheld from the people of Australia much information, under the plea that he did not wish to advantage the dealers in wheat scrip. I say, here and now, that there never should have been any dealings in wheat scrip. As soon as the Wheat Pool was established upon a fair basis, the farmer should have been paid the full price for his grain.

talk.start.para: - I said that I refused to guess at the quantity of wheat in

speech.para: Stock for the benefit of scrip investors.

talk.start.para: - If the Vice-President of the Executive Council views the matter in that way he is entitled to do so. But my own opinion is that it should not be necessary for him to guess at the quantity of wheat in stock - he should know it from actual returns. I trust that the Minister responsible for the management of the Pool will in future keep the public so informed of what is happening that it will be impossible for fortunes to be made by slumping the market to-day and causing it to rise tomorrow. The people of this country want straightforward dealing in connexion with this matter. If the Minister in the exercise of his discretion withholds certain information from the public, how can he be assured that some officer in his Department will not disclose that information to outsiders?
- In my speech I gave to honorable senators the fullest information regarding the Pool, and I explained that I could not give certain figures because we were not in possession of them.

- The Minister's remark, I take it, goes to prove the truth of my allegation that no matter what quantity of wheat is credited in the books of the Department as being in the wheat stacks, there is no guarantee that it is there. I am not blaming the Minister personally for withholding information from the public. But he must be aware that wheat scrip has been so used as to allow fortunes to be made out of the manner in which the market has been manipulated. In the matter of withholding information, need I point to the Georgeson case in New South Wales? An investigation into certain charges made in relation to that particular con- tract has just. been finished, and if Mr. Georgeson was a lucky speculator who took the great risk of buying from the New South Wales Government more than £500,000 worth of wheat without paying a single shilling deposit upon it, and of securing the Eastern market for himself, I am not going to say that he has done anything dishonorable. Far from it. Yet, not only does the evidence disclose, but the finding of the Judge shows, that on the 1st February last a certain telegram was in the possession of the Minister who was in control of the Wheat Board in New South Wales, that that telegram was submitted to the Chamber of Commerce and to various individuals in Sydney somewhere about the 5th February, but that it did not find its way to the Wheat Board until the 20th of February - the day upon which the Minister entered into the contract with Mr. Georgeson. That telegram disclosed that there was a drought, with a consequent shortage of rice, in Japan. It did not require a very intelligent man to know that if there was a shortage of rice in Japan it would be necessary to make good that shortage with wheat. Nor did it need a very smart business man to know if he could purchase £500,000 worth of wheat from the New South Wales Government, and obtain access to the Eastern market, the risk he would incur in purchasing that wheat would not be a very great one. The Department had the information to which I have referred from Mr. Suttor, its representative in Japan, on the 1st February last. That information was sent by telephone to certain public bodies in Sydney, but it was not till the 20th February that it reached the Wheat Board. Secrecy of that kind is calculated to create in the minds of the farmers but one impression, namely, that those who were responsible for the management of this Pool were not much concerned about securing for them the very best possible price.

speech.para: I venture to say that if the whole of the operations of the Pool were analyzed it would be found that there has been a deliberate attempt to thwart the intention of the Government by regarding the interests of the farmers as of secondary importance. Let me refer to the manner in which Australian wheat was sold to

Great Britain time after time. I can quite understand that persons sentimentally inclined might say that when Britain was under the stress of war, and when U-boats were blockading and threatening to starve her people, we should not have cavilled at the price at which we sold our wheat to the Mother Land. I am not going to cavil at the price now, hut I venture to say that, even under conditions like those to which I refer, the British people might well have been called upon to pay the same price for Australian wheat as their Government were prepared to pay for British-grown wheat.

talk.start.para: - Or for Canadian wheat.
- They paid full market value for Canadian wheat, which was produced within six days' steam of the Home Country.
- Can you state the price paid for Canadian wheat?
- Yes. At the time of which I am speaking it realized about 9s. per bushel, whereas the Australian farmer was getting practically only a little more than 4s. a bushel.
- Canadian wheat went up as high as 10s. per bushel.

- If, as the honorable senator says, Great Britain was getting a bargain in Australian wheat at the price mentioned, why did she not take more, so that it would not be now lying rotting in the stacks?

- The difficulty about the shipping was one reason, but that should not be an argument that our farmers should not expect, as Senator Millen put it the other day, when speaking on another question, the world's parity for their produce.
- If you had been in the position of the British Government, what would you have done?

- I would have done what the British Government did - the best for the people they were governing. If the Australian Government had acted in like manner, and had done their best for the Australian people, we would have had a great deal more money with which to meet our war loan obligations than we have at the present time. The sale of huge quantities of Australian wheat at about 4s. per bushel at a time when the British Government had fixed the price of British-grown wheat as high as 10s. per bushel was a bad business deal from the -stand-point of the Australian farmer. It is all very well to say that we get credit for helping the Mother Country when she was in danger, by letting her have our wheat for half the price she was paying to her own people. No doubt this was splendid, and our farmers have stood up to it magnificently. But it was bad business to call upon the Australian farmer - because, after all, it was the farmers and not the Australian public - to bear the entire ' burden, for while his wheat was being sold at half its price, he was being compelled to pay at exorbitant rates for all the necessaries of life, and had to pay excessive freights on his wheat.

speech.para: Some time ago I asked what was the cost, in 1914, of carrying wheat from Australia to Great Britain in privately-owned vessels, and the Minister's reply was that the freights ranged from 19s. 6d. to 32s. 6d. per tan. During the war this Government, with the deliberate intention of decreasing the margin between the price which the British people were paying for Australian wheat and' that which the British Government were paying for British wheat, increased freights in their own vessels to £7 10s. per ton. I shall not read the whole of the questions which I put to the Minister on that occasion, as they appear in Hansard, and my statements may thus be verified. Under the operation of this scheme the farmer who delivered his wheat in good order and condition gets only the proclaimed price. If 1,000 bags of first class wheat was destroyed by the mice or weevil in another State, the farmer who delivered first class wheat would have to bear his share of the loss.

talk.start.para: - No; each State bears its, own losses.

- Then I shall put it this way. If a farmer in the north-west of New South Wales, at Narrabri, for instance, delivered wheat in first class condition, and if damage were done to wheat at Goulburn, the Narrabri farmer would have to bear his share of the loss incurred by the Pool.
- Within the State, yes.

- Is that a fair business arrangement for the efficient farmer? If there had been honest dealing with the primary producer, his wheat should have been paid for on delivery, and any losses incurred would have been borne by the whole of the people of Australia.
- I suggested that last week, when you were talking about cheap bread.

- I know that my speeches always start Senator de Largie's active brain working, but, unfortunately, he sits so closely behind the Government that for most of his time here it remains inactive. When Senator de Largie talks to me about wanting cheap bread, I say that we could just as well let the people of Australia have bread at 3d. per 2-lb. loaf, and pay the farmer full value for his wheat, as pay the iron manufacturer a bonus on his product. The point I am attempting to make is that, owing to the losses that have been incurred in the working of the Wheat Pools, the wheat producer has been suffering more than any other section of the community. It may be that the Minister will say that finally the farmer will get full market value, but to that argument I reply that if, owing to hard conditions, a farmer is obliged to sell his scrip, he will not get full market value for his produce. Let me now give a few quotations showing the price of wheat in Great Britain. I go to the actual source for this information, so that my figures may not be questioned. In the House of Commons Hansard for the16th March, 1917,I find the following remarks made by Mr. Outhwaite: -

quote.para: I have seen it stated that Australian farmers last year got about 4s. a bushel, or 32s. a quarter, for their wheat, and I am interested to know why the Australian farmers are getting 32s. a quarter while the British farmers have been guaranteed from 64s. to 80s. a quarter? I want to get the price that is being paid to the Australian farmer, in order to compare it with what the British farmer is extorting.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator knows that statement to be incorrect.
- I do not want to quote the whole of the House of Commons Hansard on the subject, and the Government would take fine care that I did not do so if I attempted it.
- The honorable senator knows that the figure was 4s. 9d. and not 4s. a bushel.

- Senator Russell has himself just said that it was not 4s. 9d. per bushel, but that there was a possibility that it would reach 4s. 9d. per bushel if all went well, having regard to freight, mice, and everything else. I shall establish the correctness of these figures beyond dispute by quoting the answers of responsible Ministers in Great Britain to questions asked in the House of Commons. Honorable senators wil1 recognise, therefore, that any figures I use are submitted only after complete investigation.
- Will the . honorable senator repeat the prices he has just quoted ?

- Senator de Largie will find them in Hansard, and in. view of the fact that I have only sixty minutes in which to speak, he will excuse me for not repeating them now. From the House of Commons Hansard of the 28th March, 1917, I quote the following: -

quote.para: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Shipping Control (Sir Leo Chiozza Money), in reply'to a question asked by Mr. Outhwaite,re the freight charged on a bushel of wheat from Australia at Blue-Book rates, stated - " My right honorable friend asked me to answer this question. An exact equivalent cannot be stated, but the liners are paid at the rate of 70s. per ton, which is calculated to be equivalent to Blue-Booh rates. This may be taken to be, roughly, a rate of1s. l0?d. per bushel."
Mr. Outhwaite. Can the honorable gentleman state the rate at which wheat is now being imported from Australia?
Sir L.. Chiozza Money. Yes;1s. l0?d. per bushel is the figure for which my honorable friend asks.
Mr. Outhwaite. Is wheat being imported at the rate which has been given?
Sir. L. Chiozza Money. The answer is in the affirmative. That is the rate.

speech.para: I am submitting a sufficient number of these quotations to the Senate to show that my authority for the statements made is the Mansard report of proceedings in the House of Commons. On the 26th April, 1917, 1 find the following:-

quote.para: Mr. Outhwaite asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food, whether his attention had been drawn to the fact that through having control of shipping, the Government has been able to compel Australian farmers to accept 3!)s. per quarter for the wheat .purchased from them on which freight charge to England is 15s. per quarter, and can he say why, under these circumstances, the Government has not compelled British farmers to sell wheat at less than the maximum price, which has been fixed at 78s. per quarter?

Captain Bathurst. - The figures given in the question are inaccurate. I may add that there is no relation between the price agreed to be paid for Australian wheat under a contract made several months ago, and the price at which farmers are now compelled to sell homegrown wheat.

speech.para: I quote the following from the House of Commons Hansard report for the 30th April, 1917:-

quote.para: Mr. Outhwaite asked the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Food whether, in view of the .fact that the Government has acquired wheat from Australian farmers at 39s. 9d a quarter, with freightage to this country of 15s. a quarter, he will take immediate steps to reduce the maximum price at which British farmers may sell wheat, from 78s. a quarter to some figure more closely approximating to the cost of Australian wheat landed here?
Captain Bathurst. - I have nothing to add to the answer given to the honorable member on Thursday last (26th April, 1917).

Mr. Outhwaite. Is the honorable gentleman aware that he did not answer this question on Thursday at all? He said the figures were incorrect. Is he aware that the first figure is got from the statement made by the president of the Victorian Farmers Union dealing with prices given in Australia, and the other figure is given from the front bench?

Captain Bathurst. - I am informed by the Wheat Commission that the figure is incorrect; but it is immaterial whether it is correct or incorrect. Questions of this character are greatly to be deprecated, and render the negotiations for the purchase of wheat in other countries somewhat delicate and difficult.

Mr. Outhwaite. Is the honorable gentleman aware that his attention is drawn to the facts in this question for the purpose of showing that we are paying too high a price for British wheat, and has nothing to do with the price we pay abroad, and that we are allowing the British farmer to extort twice as much as we give the Australians ?

Captain Bathurst. - May I take the opportunity of saying that there is nothing whatever to show that there is any disparity, considering the altered conditions, between the price paid for this wheat and British wheat. The contract is one which was made several months ago, when the conditions in the world generally were wholly different from what they are to-day.

speech.para: If the Minister, or any other person, is disposed to say that these figures are incorrect let me say that ordinary well-informed people must know that, while our wheat was sold at from 32s. to 40s. per quarter, the price paid by the British Government went as high as 78s. .per quarter, or practically 10s. per bushel. I quote the following from the House of Commons Hansard report for 16th July, 1917 :-

quote.para: Mr. Lough asked the President of the Board of Trade whether quantities of wheat purchased by his Department are now lying in Australia owing to the impossibility of obtaining freight; if so, what is the total quantity, when was it .purchased, and what still remains to be shipped; -whether this wheat is all paid for, and, if so, at what .price; whether it is still in good condition, and if he anticipates it will be fit for human food when ultimately brought to this country?

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Labour (Mr. Bridgeman). - Purchases of 500,000 and 3,000,000 -tons of Australian wheat were made on behalf of Great Britain, France, and Italy, under contracts dated 3rd October, 1910 and 4th December, 1916, at the prices of 32s. and 38s. respectively, free on board. The whole of the 500,000 tons has been paid for and shipped; of the 3,000,000 tons, part only has been shipped, and under the terms of the contract, full payment is not yet due for the -whole amount. The wheat is in good condition, and it is anticipated that it will be fit for human consumption on arrival in this country.....

speech.para: On the 24th July the following statement is reported to have been made by Mr. Runciman : -

item.para: observe from newspaper reports that wheat can be purchased in the United States at about 10s. per bushel, or 80s. a quarter- We were bound, therefore, to make very large purchases in Australia for our own security in regard to our food supplies, and we did that on generous terms to the Australian Government and the Australian farmers, and both got something out of it. Certainly, the Australian Government got something out of it, and they were entitled to do so.

speech.para: There was still another statement made in the House of Commons by Mr. Runciman, who, I think I am correct in saying, was a Minister at that time. I have a recollection of some pleasant remarks which Mr. Hughes had to make about him when he came back here. Mr. Runciman is reported in the Hansard of the House of Commons for the 24th July, 1917, to have said: - ( It is a most remarkable fact that ever since the Government fixed the carriage of wheat across the Atlantic at Blue-Book rates, the price of wheat has steadily gone up. As freights went clown the loaf went up. That was duc to the fact that the American grower, and, possibly, the merchant, succeeded in making far larger profits than ever they anticipated; undoubtedly they have made large profits out of the privations of Europe. We are not in the happy position of having the American Government in full sympathy with us in this and other matters, 'and' I observe from newspaper reports that a fixed price has been made, and that wheat can be purchased in the United States at something over 2 dollars a bushel - 2.25 dollars or 2.30 dollars - that is to> say, about 10s. a bushel, or 80s. a quarter.

Without occupying any more of my time, which is so valuable now, I think that I have already .proved to the satisfaction of every one what I set out to prove, and that is that the Australian farmer; through the war, received only half the world's parity for his wheat.

talk.start.para: - He was also further away from the world's market than were the producers of other countries.
- Senator Gardiner has left out a number of other factors. He is dodging them.

- I am 'not dodging them; but, under the conditions under which debates are now conducted in the Senate, one has not more than time to gallop through what he desires to say. I find that Elder, Smith, and Company have stated that -

quote.para: The freight of wheat to San Francisco is 05s. per ton (5 per cent, of which goes to the Commonwealth as commission), equals 2s. 7d. a bushel.

speech.para: The Australian farmers' wheat is sold through a shipping firm, who quote .a high price for carrying it, and 5. per cent, of this goes to the Commonwealth Government.

talk.start.para: - No; to the Australian Wheat Boards of the different States concerned.
- I have quoted the statement of Elder, Smith, and Company, and I am glad to have the Minister's indorsement that 5 per cent, goes to the Wheat Pool.
- One and a quarter per cent, is retained by the Commonwealth and 3$ per cent, is given to the State Wheat Boards.

- I find that on the 15th March Mr. Outhwaite stated that British farmers were guaranteed 64s. to SOs. per quarter, or from Ss. to 10s. per bushel. On the 24th of July Mr. Lough -stated- that Australian wheat was bought at 32s. and 38s. a quarter, and it was understood that freight was 13s* a quarter. The Minister says that the fact that there is a surplus from the Wheat Pool is a proof of its success. The Minister's statement that there is a surplus is a proof of its success in spite of, I will not say the bad management, but the lack of experience, which had to be gained in the management of the Pool before it became -successful. But I have made, the quotations I .have given to the Senate to show that it is to the farmers, and to them alone, that credit is due for sending wheat to feed the British people, and that they gave that wheat at half its price, and did so without grumbling. Now that that wheat has gone, and the war is. over, the Government are asking to extend the Pool over another harvest or two, but they are not proposing to protect the farmer from private speculators. The farmers are as large purchasers in the world's markets of boots, clothing, arid other necessaries of life as are the members of any other section of the community. Whilst the Government are proposing to extend the Wheat Pool until their contracts are completed, they do not make any statement of their intention to extend in other directions; for the benefit of the farmer, what has proved to be a good system of bargaining with, their wheat and other produce.

speech.para: I do not wish to leave out of consideration one very. important factor. Just before it was my good fortune to leave the

Government, with a view to protecting the farmer quite a number of ships were purchased by the Government to carry abroad the produce of farmers and other persons. A high price was paid for those ships, as they could not be purchased otherwise at the time. But it never was intended by the Government which purchased them that, once they came into their hands, they were to be used for profiteering purposes in just the same way as privately-owned ships were used. I may remind honorable senators that before the war the rate of freight on wheat from Australia to London was from 6£d. to less than 10½d. per bushel or from 19s. to 323. per ton. What are we to say of a Government which, without any very considerable additional cost in the handling of their ships, charged the Wheat Pool, and that is to say the Australian farmer, as high as 150s. per ton, or about 4s. per bushel, freight on wheat to London? I invite the attention of the Minister in charge of the Wheat Pool to this matter, and he «an give me an answer one way or tie other as to the exact figures when he comes to reply to the debate. The figures will show that the profits on carrying the farmers' wheat to London by the vessels which the first Hughes- Government purchased paid for those vessels, and thus the people who paid for them were the farmers.

talk.start.para: - No ; the bulk of the profits were made from .back loadings. Wheat is not a very payable cargo for any ship.

- The Vice-President of the Executive Council has gained a considerable amount of experience in connexion with the Wheat Pool; but it is idle for him to say that wheat is not a profitable cargo, when private shipping companies carried wheat at 19s. per ton before the war and, under his management of the Wheat Pool, the freight rose to £7 10s. per ton.
- I say that the bulk of the profits made by the Commonwealth steam-ships were made from back loadings.

- It seems that I must bring documentary evidence to prove everything I say. T am in a position to quote a return showing the wheat shipped by vessels of the Commonwealth up to the 25th November, 1918. I am sorry that I have not later figures ta quote, but since that time the freights have been increased. The following is the statement: -

speech.para: I have quoted the return, and it is a complete answer to the statement made by the Minister.

talk.start.para: - Can you quote the rates charged by the private shipping companies, and tell us whether they were as low, or lower?

- I have always looked upon Senator de Largie as a relentless and hard-hearted man, and when he asks me to quote more than I have already done, during my limited time, I absolutely refuse. I find it quite impossible to even approach the question intelligently in the' time allowed. What have I put these figures before the Senate for? To prove that the Wheat Pool has shown a profit, and that the farmers of

speech.para: Australia have supplied the people of Great Britain with wheat at about half the cost at which it could be obtained in that country. The Commonwealth Government not only paid for the ships they purchased in three years, but they charged the farmers 150s. per ton freight when the ruling rate before the war was 19s. per ton. The Government have been telling the farmers that they have made a good deal. That is Senator Russell's idea of a good deal. He pays no regard to the cost to the primary producer.

talk.start.para: - All the profits of the Pool go to the. farmers. I never spoke ofprofits.

- I wonder if it is too late now for the Government to fix a fair rate at which to carry farmers' wheat. I do not say that it should be based on pre-war rates, but wheat should be carried at a reduced price, and the profits should go into the Pool to enable the farmers to participate in them. The farmers have to pay the world's parity for everything they use, and why should they not be allowed to receive full value for their produce? Having neglected, owing to lack of business aptitude, to secure the world's price for the farmers' produce, the Government should charge only a fair freight for grain, and give the balance to the people who have earned it. I find that I' have left this important question practically untouched, because there are a lot of important matters in connexion with the Pool that should be dealt with. What happened in the seeking for these extended powers by the Government in another place? The Minister who introduced the Bill quoted the opinions of an array of distinguished barristers regarding the powers of the Commonwealth to act in this way, but I have the presumption to differ from the opinions of those distinguished barristers. As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, this legislation will remain in operation only until one firm with sufficient capital behind it appeals, when it will be found to be wholly unconstitutional. In introducing the measure in another place the Acting Attorney-General (Mr. Groom) endeavoured to justify his action, and he would not have been driven to that extremity if he had not grave doubts concerning its legality. Seeing that the Government doubt their constitutional powers, and that they believe that these concerns can be successfully carried on by the Commonwealth, it would be better to ask the people of Australia to grant them the powers they need.

talker.name: GIVENS, Thomas
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon T Givens

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable senator's time has expired.
- Shut out! and wool, dairy produce, flax, and other matters that need attention, untouched.

para.inline: Extension of time granted, on motion by SenatorReid.

talk.start.para: - I will accept an extension of one hour. I cannot touch the remaining subjects in half-an-hour.
- The motion is for an extension of half-an-hour. Under the Standing Orders, a longer extension cannot be granted.
- I decline to proceed.

. - I regret that Senator Gardiner has not seen fit to accept an extension of time in terms of the motion moved by Senator Reid. I am entirely in sympathy with him, and realize that it is impossible to deal with an important Bill in such a limited time as is allowed by the new standing order.

speech.para: During the war period the Government practically controlled the whole of the import and export trade of the Commonwealth, as well as a good deal of its interna] 'trade, and their activities extended over most of the important commercial undertakings within the Commonwealth. The transactions of the Government represented, approximately, £400,000,000 sterling, and this is the first time that Parliament has been asked for approval or disapproval of, what has been going on and what is proposed next year. The Senate should, and will, give attention to some of the weaknesses of governmental control of commercial activities, as evidenced in the past. 1 believe the Senate will endeavour to make some improvements, so that the lessons of the past may be of practical use to us.

The Bill proposes to extend the control over dairy produce, wool, skins, flax, sugar, and wheat until varying specific dates next year. I understand that contracts have been made in regard to these commodities, and that the legal luminaries the Government called to their counsel have said that the measure will be perfectly constitutional.

I notice the absence from this Bill of any attempt to control metals, and I hope no further control is intended. It is "to be hoped that governmental control of this very important primary production will end on the expiration of the War Precautions Regulations. I believe a silent vote on this matter will condone a good deal 'of what we hope will be rectified in the future in connexion with our commercial activities of the last four years. This is the most important measure we have had before us for the last two years. The Minister, in introducing it told us that it was really five Bills in one, and that each division was a Bill in itself. I am sorry that my time is so limited, owing to the passage of the new standing order, and I may have to ask the Senate for an extension to enable me to fully analyze some of the important provisions of the Bill. I regard the measure as one which has been brought in by the Government to keep faith with Parliament. The explicit promise was made, in connexion with the discussion of the extension of the War

Precautious Regulations, that before very long the Government would ask for parliamentary authority to extend the powers which up to then had been granted and exercised under the War Precautions Act. The difficulties of -the Government have been very great. There has been the enormous factor of the war.. There has been the long and dangerous transit to our overseas markets. We remember the first days of the war, when the outlook was black, and when some of us, perhaps, were in a nervy condition ; and, indeed, when, possibly, a panic was not far distant. The conception of Wheat Pools and of Government control in wartime was, in my opinion, sound. We were a great primary producing country. We had raw products to sell - far more than we required for home consumption. W«e had the question of finance to consider. We were compelled to play, at that stage, for safety and caution. We were groping in the dark. We had faith in our cause, but the end could not be foreseen. All those factors are a condonation of what the Government has done in regard to its various controls during the war. Australia has come out of her difficulties fairly well. True, we have had unofficial dictators, some tyranny, a great deal of secrecy, and much incompetence. Administration has not always been satisfactory. A case could be established, in connexion with Government activities, based upon the contention that we have sold cheap and bought dear. But I do not propose to be wise after the event, and to be hypercritical in connexion with the tremendous and unforeseen difficulties arising from the war. I hope, though, that as the result of our being able to enter upon much freer discussion now that the war is over, the blunders of the past will be rectified, and that many hard-learned lessons of the past will be applied to improve present and future administration.

Of all the activities of the Government, Senator Russell has rightly remarked that wheat control has been the most unique. Wheat constitutes the vastest bulk of our produce; it requires the greatest amount of tonnage to transport; it is the most perishable of all the controlled commodities. It is liable to pests; and the Government was caught, when the pests developed, with primitive storage arrangements. I arn sorry that the Minister, in his speech, still continued upon that optimistic plane where he has all along dwelt in hi- relations with wheat control. He was still somewhat indefinite and inconclusive; and his figures, unless subjected to very careful analysis, do not lead us far. I am sorry that the Minister did not see fit, two years ago, when we sustained such big losses as an outcome of our primitive storage arrangements, to take the country into his confidence, and strike a pessimistic note.

talk.start.para: - All the complaints have been that I was too pessimistic.

- Had the truth been told, the farmers - who are the owners of the wheat - would have been prepared for the losses which must surely arise. In addition to those losses, there have been abnormal expenses per bushel. None of the Ministerial statements issued upon the subject has even hinted at the abnormal expenses incurred in connexion with the handling and marketing of our wheat.

speech.para: I propose to devote my speech upon these "five Bills in one" to some detailed analysis of the wheat position. I believe the farmers want to know where they are. Month after month, the press has been calling for some clarification of the position. I propose to show, so far as I am able, with the help of figures collected from various sources, what position the farmer is in at the present time. I shall attempt to show the statistical position in relation to wheat still held for sale. My figures lead me to the conclusion that we shall be at least 24,000,000 bushels short when the four Pools are cleared up, but we may be able to learn what the value of scrip really is. The abnormal losses, and the great expenses per bushel incurred in placing the wheat f.o.b., will show that the farmer's net return will amount to barely 4s. per bushel on the average of the four Pools.

talk.start.para: - You are a long way at sea.

- If the Minister will be patient I shall quote figures showing how I have arrived at that opinion. As a consequence of the unsatisfactory position from the stand-point of the farmer, wheat-growing is declining. I suggest that for the next two or three years li'beral treatment be given to the farmer, whose net return in connexion with the pooling operations of the Government, particularly as compared with the world's parity, is going to prove so disappointingly small.

speech.para: I have before me a mass of rather complicated figures. I desire to start in relation to a period which will synchronize with official statements made in connexion with the wheat scheme in another place, and with the issue of official figures by the Australian Wheat Board. At no other time in the history of the scheme can I synchronize the two; and the figures that I am about to quote will have to do with the period from about 23rd June to 2nd or 3rd July. In another place the Minister responsible stated, when explaining this Bill, that during the operations of the scheme there had been received for realization 468,000,000 bushels, or 13,430,000 tons.

talk.start.para: - I corrected that item of 13,000,000 tons.

- I shall deal with that later. This statement agrees with those issued from time to time by the Wheat Board up to the 23rd June. That body supplied the information that the wheat received in the 1915-16 Pool, or the "A " Pool, was 163,374,000 bushels; in the 1916-17 Pool, or the " B " Pool, 138,275,000 bushels; in the 1917-18 Pool, or the " C " Pool, 103,342,000 bushels; and, in the 1918-19 Pool, or the "D" Pool, 64,796,000 -bushels; a grand total of 469,787,000 bushels. Those figures do not constitute quite the whole of the wheat grown in the Commonwealth. No doubt, a few million bushels have criss-crossed about the country, and have been retained for local consumption; but that grand total comprises all the wheat put into the Pools. The Minister stated in another place, on the 2nd July, that sales overseas by the Board have amounted to 6,050,000 tons, and that of this quantity there had been shipped 5,200,000 tons. The Acting Prime Minister (Mr. Watt) stated on 27th June that the amount of money involved in sales of wheat to the British Government was £30,333,000; that was, in regard to 500,000 and 3,000,000 tons of wheat. The value of the wheat delivered in respect of those contracts - the Acting Prime Minister said was £24,657,000, and the amount advanced over and above the value of wheat delivered to date is £5,676,000. According, then, to the Acting Prime Minister's statement, the amount of wheat yet to be delivered and paid for was approximately, 650,000 tons. The Acting Attorney-General (Mr. Groom) stated on the 2nd July that there were 850,000 tens still to shiip. The Acting Prime Minister's statement referred only to the British Government's contracts; and, knowing that orders from other countries had been placed with the Australian Wheat Board, it is reasonable for me to assume that by that date there would have been another 100,000 tons sold, but not shipped and not paid for. To reconcile the statements of the Acting Prime Minister and the Acting Attorney-General, however, I will assume that that tonnage is 200,000. I shall show, on the basis of those official figures, what a great discrepancy will be discovered upon the clean-up of the whole of the Pools.

speech.para: The most 'interesting point of all with those people who are interested in the wheat scheme is. how much wheat is there left to sell ? For the purpose of elucidating that, we must analyze operations from two stand-points; first, theoretically, the Wheat Board's figures; and, secondly, various statements made in Parliament, which I have repeated. The announcements of Mr. Groom have also included the statement that these were the figures after allowing for Commonwealth consumption of wheat to the end of the year. He said that after allowing for that item, we still had 2,000,000 tons for sale. That announcement was a few days afterwards confirmed by Mr. Pitt, the accountant, or secretary, of the Wheat Board, who said, in effect, that after the sale of 1,000,000 tons - the last - was made, if the British Government exercised its option over the 500.000 tons, there would only remain 500,000 in the Pool. The shippers' stocks of wheat and flour on 23rd June last, Wheat Board figures, were 147,808,000 bushels. The consumption of wheat in Australia to the end of the year, based on an average of 2J bushels per head, will be, according to Knibbs, 13,750,000 bushels. This quantity, deducted from that which was in the Pool on 23rd June, would leave 134,058,000 bushels. Now, Mr. Groom's figures are based on the assumption that there are 35 bushels of wheat in a ton, and if we accept the Acting Prime Minister's statement, that 650.000 tons have yet to be delivered to the British Government for payment received, the shippers' stocks of wheat and flour would be further reduced by 22,750,000 bushels. These quantities deducted from the 134,058,000 bushels would leave in the Pool, theoretically - after provision had been made for six months' local consumption - 111,308,000 bushels yet to be realized. The Minister for Works and Railways (Mr. Groom), in introducing the Bill in another place, stated that we still had for sale 2,000,000 tons of wheat. After allowing for the 200,000 tons sold to various Governments, there is thus a discrepancy of 34,308,000 bushels between the quantity which, theoretically, ought to be in the Pool and- the quantity which the Minister says is still for sale. I think that the following table will make these calculations clearer: -

In dealing with this theoretical deficiency, I propose to reply to Senator Russell in connexion with the correction which he made in his tonnage figures last Friday. Although Mr. Groom has based his calculations upon the assumption that 35 bushels of wheat will weigh a ton, those who know anything about the matter know that it takes 37J bushels to weigh a ton. I must, therefore, make a contingency allowance in connexion with these figures, and I propose to make that allowance, not 5,000,000, but 10,000,000 bushels, because Mr. Groom himself may have allowed for more than the actual bare requirements of the Commonwealth for the balance of the year.

talk.start.para: - The period dealt with by the honorable senator covers from 21st to 27th June. But shipments are going on busily every day, and new returns may completely alter the figures in respect to the operations of the Pool in the course of two or three days.

- The Minister's observation will not affect my figures in the slightest degree, because they are based on the statistics of the Federal Wheat Board up to 23rd June last. Further, I do not think that shipping is proceeding at such express speed as to materially interfere with them. I have reduced the theoretical deficiency - based on the statements which have already been made - of 34,500,000 bushels by a contingency allowance of 10,000,000 bushels, to 24,500,000 bushels. I am quite aware that on some of the crops there has been an increase of weight. But I am not now dealing with the profit to the Pool which must result -from that increase - an increase which will, perhaps, amount in all to nearly 4,000,000 bushels. Rather am I dealing with the actual losses which will be incurred in connexion with the administration of the Pool. As Senator Gardiner has pointed out, it may be that very many more certificates have been issued in connexion with the receipt of wheat at country railway stations than suffice to cover wheat which has actually been delivered there. That will be a loss to the Pool, and must eventually be a loss to the farmers of this country.

speech.para: It is interesting to endeavour to analyze in what States these losses are likely to occur. Senator Russell said that 3,821,000 bushels of the 1915-16 crop still remain in South Australia. Without questioning his statement in any way my information is that no South Australian wheat can be stacked for four years and remain in good condition at the end of that period. I prefer, therefore, to believe that this 3,821,000 bushels is represented 'by dust and refuse.

talk.start.para: - Why, the best stacks in Australia are to be found at Port Pirie.

- But they contain the wheat of other crops than that of 1915-16. South Australia has been particularly unfortunate in regard to shipping, in that she has not enjoyed the facilities -which .have been enjoyed by other States. However, as my time is limited, and as I desire to present a somewhat complex argument in which I must set out my figures consecutively, I shall be glad if the Minister will allow me to proceed without interruption. On the 1916-17 crop I estimate that there will be a loss in New South Wales of at least 6,000,000 bushels. As a matter of fact, I think that loss has been almost admitted. I believe that upon this crop there will be a loss in South Australia of 4,000,000 bushels. Upon the 1917-18 crop, which in New South Wales and South Australia has been considerably damaged bv weevil, I estimate a loss of 3,000,000 bushels in the former State, and of 2,000,000 in the latter. There will, of course, be some losses in Victoria. Those losses possibly, without allowing for any addition owing to the increased weight of the wheat will amount to anything up to 4,000,000 bushels in all in that State. So that the total losses on the figures which I have presented is 22,821,000 bushels. Assuming that there is none of the 1915-16 crop left, after these losses have been deducted, there would remain for realization 27,606,000 bushels of the 1916-17 crop, 39,407,000 bushels of the 1917-18 crop, and 57,974,000 bushels of the 1 918-19 crop, a total of 124,987,000 bushels. Of this quantity the British Government have to get 650,000 tons, which have been paid for, but which have not yet been delivered, so that on the figures which I have submitted the stocks available for sale will be 4,856,000 bushels of the 1916-17 crop, 39,407,000 bushels of the 1917-18 crop, and 57,974,000 bushels of the 1918-19 crop, or a total of 102,237,000 bushels. Now, I must deduct from this amount a certain quantity in order that the British Government may receive 37. bushels per ton instead of the ' 35 bushels estimated by Mr. Groom. When I have done this I think that the quantity of wheat remaining to be sold at the time these statements were made would amount approximately to 100,000,000 bushels.

speech.para: A good deal has been said both inside and outside of Parliament about the gambling in wheat scrip which has been proceeding, on the Stock Exchanges of Australia. I am in full agreement with Senator- Gardiner that no gambling ought to have been permitted in this scrip. I do not agree with Senator Russell that the publication of information in connexion with the Wheat Pool is calculated to play into the hands of wheat scrip speculators.

talk.start.para: - I made no such statement. I said that I gave all the information that I could, but that I declined to guess the state of affairs when certain figures were not in my possession.

- A month or two ago - even last year, I believe - statements were made by the Minister to the effect that most of the wheat scrip was in second hands, and that gambling in it was proceeding- gambling which he did not intend to encourage.

- I think that the honorable senator misses my point. As the responsible Minister connected with the Pool, if I say that I believe a certain quantity of wheat is in stock the public will accept that statement as authoritative. Consequently, I am not going to do that.

- The Sydney Morning Herald of last Thursday published the State scrip figures up to Wednesday last. These were made up by the State Wheat Board office', and show that in New South Wales, for all the Pools which have been established, there is not 25 per cent, of the wheat scrip in second hands - that is to say, in the hands of speculators. Various estimates have been made by brokers and others, but nobody seems to know accurately what is the position. However, I think it . is fair to assume, on the figures I have quoted, that in New South Wales considerably more than 50 per cent. of the scrip issued in connexion with all the Pools still remains in the hands of the original owners, and that considerably less than 50 per cent, has found . its way into the hands of speculators. . Whatever we may now say is the value of the scrip, the point is that it is of far more importance . to the farmers than, the speculators, because they hold the bulk of it. In analyzing the scrip position, I have taken the average net market rates as on the 14th July of this year, and my calculation as to the total value of scrip in all the Pools has been arrived at on the following basis: - New South Wales : - " A " Pool, 1. 7-16d. ; " B,"1½d. ; "C." 9¾ d ; " D," 6d. Victoria -"A,"1d.; "B,"7¾d.; "C,"10d.; "D," 4d. South Australia-" A," 7-16d. ; " B," 3d.; "C," 9d.; " D," 4d. Western Australia- " A," Id; " B,"1½d.; " C," Sd. ; " D," 3½d. These are the net prices and have been arrived at after deducting 4d. in the case of New South Wales, for freight in respect of " B " and " C " Pools; 4£d. railage in Victoria in respect of " B " and " C " Pools; and 2¼d. freight for "B" and "C" Pools in South Australia. A calculation of the money that will be required to redeem the scrip at these net figures on 14th July of this year gives a sum of £8,443,418. If there were only 100,000,000 bushels of wheat in the Wheat Pools actually saleable on the dates at which these figures were compiled, I think we could assume that the balance in the 1916-17 Pool, 4,856,000 bushels, would realize 4s. 6d. per bushel net, or a total of £1,092,600; that the 39,407,000 bushels' in the 1917-18 Pool would realize 5s. ; or a total of £9,851,750; and that the 55,737,000 bushels in the 1918-19 Pool would return 5s. 6d. net, or a total of £15,327,675, giving a total for the 100,000,000 bushels of £26,272,025. The overdraft on 23rd June of this year was £18,335,000, which, deducted from the amount realizable on the basis stated for the 100,000,000 bushels, would show a credit of £7,937,025. The net value of the wheat scrip on 14th July I have shown to be £8,443,418. Therefore, on these figures, the loss in market value of the wheat scrip on 14th July would appear to be £506,393, without taking into account any further expenditure. I believe there is a good deal of evidence available to buttress the calculations which I have made. For instance, although we hear of high prices being paid for wheat, we must not forget the heavier expenditure incurred. For the "A" crop the expenditure, as spread over the whole crop, is 7.3d., without allowing for railway freight. For the "B" Pool, the rate is 11.18d. ; for the " C " Pool, 9.8d. ; and for the " D," 5.38d. per bushel so far. I think that the total cost of the realization of the wheat in the four Pools cannot be less, including railway freight, than Is. for the "A" wheat; Is. 6d. for "B" wheat; Is. 3d. for " C " wheat ; and Is. at least for " D " wheat.
- Are you allowing anything for realizable assets, such as timber ?

- No. Another thing the farmers are entitled to know in connexion with Wheat Board finance is whether or not the whole of the wheat in the Pools has yet been paid for. In an actuarial survey of the statements given to the public by the Wheat Board, I find that the sum paid to the growers at the prices set out for the respective Pools - 4s. 9d., 3s. 3d., 3s. 3d., and 4s. 4d- is nearly £8,000,000 less than ought to have been paid, based on the quantity of wheat which the Wheat Board admits has been received into the Pools. I understand that this includes railway freights on the A " and " D " Pools ; but this, reckoned on the average of 4d. per bushel, will not amount to more than £4,000,000 sterling, so that, on the face of it, it looks as if £1,000,000 or £2,000,000 or more is still owing to the growers. Coming hack for a moment to the position in New South Wales, I believe that less care has been exercised in connexion with the wheat storage there than in the other wheat-producing States of the Commonwealth. I am sorry to say that Mr.

speech.para: Grahame himself has made statements, before a Royal Commission, which lead one to the conclusion that there is going to be a heavy loss in connexion with the 1916-17 wheat. Farmers have been paid in New South Wales 3s. 3d. per bushel so far, and Mr. Grahame said that, up to the time of the Georgeson sale, 21,000,000 bushels of the 1916-17 wheat had been disposed of at an average of 4s. 3d. per bushel fio.b., leaving a balance of about 11,000,000 bushels, according to the books of the State Wheat Office, still to be sold. With such a definite statement as that, we are able to throw some light upon the real position of the 1916-17 Pool in New South Wales in comparison with the other States and other Pools. At 4s. 3d. per bushel, 21,000,000 bushels will realize £4,462,500. It is not reasonable to assume that in New South Wales we are likely to get more than 4s. net for the balance of 11,000,000 bushels, in view of the fact that it is the refuse of the whole of the Pool.

talk.start.para: - The 1916-17 wheat was "pinched" before it was harvested.

- Exactly. Now, 11,000,000 bushels at 4s. would amount to £2,200,000, or a total for the 33,000,000 bushels in New South Wales of £6,662,500. There has been advanced to the farmers £4,990,000, and as 32,050,000 bushels at 3s. 3d. amounts to £5,208,125, apparently there is a sum of £218,125 still owing to the farmers in connexion with that Pool. Expenses to 23rd June, 1919, amount to £1,718,000, so that there is against this realization % sum of £6,926,125 altogether, showing a loss on this Pool if all the wheat is saved and sold, of £263,625. But if the Pool is short to the extent of 6,000,000 bushels at 3s. 3d., the loss will be £1,238,625 in New South Wales on the 1916-17 Pool alone.
- Have you allowed for deductions in deliveries at railway stations.

- I have taken the figures as given to the public. If we examine the Minister's own statement, made so recently as last week, we shall find a good deal to confirm the figures which I have presented. Approximately, they are not very far from the truth.

speech.para: The Minister stated that, approximately, there were 30,000,000 bushels of wheat yet for sale, not allowing for loss by mice, weevils, fermentation, rain, theft, or by other causes. In view of the admissions that have been made in New South Wales in connexion with the Georgeson inquiry, and the re-adjustments made by the Wheat Board itself last week, it is fair to assume that from this quantity of 30,000,000 bushels, a large amount will have to be deducted.

talk.start.para: - I said that local supplies up to December would amount to another million of money.

- The Minister's figures show, after deducting bank overdraft, a credit to the Pool of only £1,479,000; but if there is only 10,000,000 bushels available out of the 30,000,000 bushels in the Pool in all the States, and if this is sold at 5s. at stations, a total of £2,500,000 will be arrived at as the amount to be further credited to the Pool, plus local sales of £500,000 a month, for five months, representing another £2,500,000 sterling, or a total of £6,479,000 altogether; whereas the net value of wheat scrip on 23rd June of this year was £8,276,000, against which there is apparently only £6,500,000 available.
- If any person is foolish enough to pay higher than market price for scrip, we give no guarantee that he will get his money.

- Of course not, but the Minister should tell the Senate whether or not all the wheat is paid for, and, if not, how much remains, because that sum must be added to the debit of the Pool. The figures, so far as I can thresh them out on the Ministerial statement alone, show that a couple of million of pounds sterling is still owing to the farmers.
- There must be an omission somewhere from the honorable senator's figures.

- I shall go back a moment in order to make my statement clear in this regard. Take, for instance, the " B " Pool, which is three years old. The Federal Wheat Board figures, dated 23rd June, state that there has been paid to the growers, in connexion with the Pool, at the rate of 3s. 3d. per bushel, the sum of £22,163,000. The same statement sets out that of this crop there were 13S,275,000 bushels in the Pool. This number, multiplied by 3s. 3d., will give £22,469,687. In other words, the Wheat Board say that they have paid to the growers, in connexion with " B " Pool, a sum of £300,000 less than the growers are entitled to, in view of the number of bushels of wheat in the Pool. This is an illustration of the point I wish to make with respect to the amount of money that is owing to the growers in connexion with their Pool operations.

- I think that in connexion with the " B " Pool, to which the honorable senator refers, 3s. per 'bushel was advanced at first, less railway freight. There had to be a deduction of the railway freight from that amount.

- The Wheat Board figures show that the sum of 3s. 3d. per bushel has been. 'paid to the farmers, and why complicate the position by criss-crossing with freight on one crop and not on another? The country is entitled to the most explicit, frank, and straightforward declaration of the wheat position that can possibly be given by the Minister. I hope that he will make such a declaration, after the remarks I have made to-day, because we all know that the care of the wheat is a responsibility of the State Governments, and not of the Federal Government, and the responsibility of the losses is not a responsibility of the Federal Government, but of State officials. I am not here criticising the Minister.
- I am aware of that, and I am trying to help the honorable senator.

- I want it to go forth to the country that the losses that have occurred are not the responsibility, or due to the fault, of the Federal Government, but that whatever responsibilities, fault, or incompetence there may be, it is the concern of the State Governments, and has nothing to do with the Federal Government, or with the conception of the Pool.

speech.para: Now, as to the farmers' point of view: The farmers rightly claim that the Government commandeered their wheat and that they are not liable for the losses that have occurred. I am sure that, whether we like it or not, there is a controversy looming as to whether the general body of the taxpayers should pay or whether the whole of the loss should be averaged over the four Pools. In this connexion, I should like to refer to an interjection made by the Vice-President of the Executive Council whilst Senator Gardiner was speaking this afternoon. The Minister said that each State will pay its own losses. I understand that an agreement was arrived at some months ago whereby the losses would be pooled over the whole of the operations of the wheat-growers. It is certainly understood in New South Wales that Victorian farmers will very likely have to make up, by the good management in Victoria, the bad management in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: -That is not so. There is no foundation for that rumour.

- The position is clarified by the utterance of the Minister in charge of the Bill, that where the State authorities have been incompetent, careless, or unlucky, the State concerned will have to stand the losses made and will have to be responsible to its own farmers.
- That is a clear and correct statement of the position.

-From the figures I have given in connexion with the Wheat Pool I think we can judge, with a reasonable amount of accuracy, how much the farmers are going to net in connexion with the Government operations. If those figures are followed closely it will be seen that the wheat farmer is not going to average more than 4s. per bushel net, as the expenses already charged, with the losses yet to be adjusted, and the miscellaneous squaring up which will have to be made, will probably double the pre-war cost of putting the wheat from the country station f.o.b. the ship. Although, in my opinion, the average selling price is likely to be 5s. per bushel throughout the whole of the Government's activities, the farmer is not going to get more than 4s. of this amount.

speech.para: Now the question arises whether this will pay. My honorable friend, Senator Lynch, made a very valuable contribution to the subject of wheat-growing last year. He laid before us the increasing cost of wheat-growing, and placed before the Senate a good many statements to indicate the hard lot of the wheat farmer in many parts of Australia; We know that the average crop during the last ten years has been only about 12 bushels per acre, and if the farmer does not get more than 4s. per bushel he -cannot average a gross return of more than £2 8s. per acre as the result of his exertions. There has been some inquiry into the cost of wheat-growing in New South Wales. I am not quite sure whether it is official or not, but one of the conclusions come to in connexion with that inquiry was, that the cost of wheat-growing to-day is, approximately, £2 per acre. Therefore, if in war time the Australian farmer is only going to get an average return of £2 8s. per acre of wheat that he sows, and this is going to cost him £2 per acre to grow, there does not seem to be very much encouragement for wheat-farming, and it is no wonder that nearly, 4,000,000 acres have gone out of cultivation for wheat since the beginning of the war. I think that fact is very eloquent testimony to the hard luck of the farmers.

talk.start.para: - I think that the advance in the price of wool has something to do with it.

- How share farmers have got on I do not know. I believe that land has gone out of cultivation for wheat, not only because of a shortage of labour and the enhanced prices obtained for meat and wool, but also because of the low prices that the wheat farmer has been getting under war conditions.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Shannon). - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

para.inline: Extension of time granted, on motion by

talk.start.para: - I have to thank the Senate for the courtesy extended to me. I shall be unable in the short time at my disposal to deal now with the bigger and more important questions of wool and all subsidiary industries, but I shall endeavour in Committee to deal with these questions and those affecting sugar, wool, and dairying in the most effective way possible under the new standing order.

speech.para: I have mentioned the great secrecy which has been observed in connexion with our wheat operations. It is public property that censorship was exercised in connexion with statements attempted to be made as to the wheat position. I would urge upon the Minister that the policy of keeping in the dark the growers, the men who own the wheat, whose property, and very often whose all, it is, has been the one fault and folly of the Wheat Pool, and has tended more than anything else to make the wheat scheme unpopular.

talk.start.para: - I do not think it is quite fair to say that the growers have been kept in the dark. I gave my assurance to the Senate that I had published all the information I possibly could give.. I ask Senator Pratten to accept that, because his statement that the growers have been kept in the dark will not read very well in print. I do not think that he quite means what that statement would convey.

- No personal reflection upon the Minister is intended. I think he will realize that the wheat position is an extremely complicated one to the ordinary man, and that it is almost impossible for him to figure out what the owners will eventually get for their wheat unless some help in the matter is given by those of us who have tried to understand the position, and some further assistance is given by the Minister himself. I trust that I have his assurance that he will endeavour to clear up the position and face it. I repeat that the losses that have been incurred in wheat stacking and by State administrative control are no responsibilities of his. I am sorry that he did not face the position some two years ago. I think that if he had done so a good deal of friction might have been avoided and much dissatisfaction prevented. I trust that as a result of the observations that have been made to-day the Minister will be as frank as he can with the country in this matter.
- I have always been so.

- Looking abroad, what do the farmers say? They read that the Government of the United States of America guaranteed their wheat farmers last year 9s. 2d. per bushel for all the wheat they grew, that that crop was marketed at little or no loss to the country, and that the same guarantee is being given by the Government of the United States of America this year of a further 9s. 2d. per bushel for all the wheat that the farmers of that country can grow. They read, also, that the British Government have guaranteed their farmers 9s. per bushel, and that the Canadian Government have guaranteed farmers in Canada 8s. 4d. per bushel for their crop. I agree with Senator Gardiner tha't when the Australian farmer reads of these conditions prevailing in other Dominions and other countries he is rightly critical of the amount he nets for his crop.

speech.para: The question of freights has been mentioned, and the amount which the Australian farmer is called upon to pay in freight. I have given some little attention to this phase of the matter, but I am driven' to conclusions other than those arrived at by Senator Gardiner. One of the conclusions to which I am driven is that the sum of £1,000,000 per day approximately that was collected by the British Government in excess profit taxation has been collected from a hundred different sources all over the world, and that the Australian farmer has practically paid some of it. Wheat freights vary, and I believe the rate to-day is £5 per ton to Falmouth. According to a statement made by the Prime Minister wheat freights have been as high as £11 per ton.

talk.start.para: - How would that work out per bushel?

- Every £1 per ton in freight means about 6£d. per bushel. If a war-time freight from Australia to Europe, including shipowners profit, is set down at, say, £3 per ton it is evident that the British Government did, or should have collected from 60 to SO per cent, of the abnormal profit, which was the difference between £3 and the freight actually charged. If the average of excess profit was anything from £2 to £6 per ton - the British Government would be entitled to at least 30s. to £4 per ton under their excess war-time profits tax, which would represent from a minimum of 9fd. to a maximum of nearly 2s. 6d. on every bushel of Australian wheat shipped abroad during war time.
- Would that account for the discrepancy between the price paid for Australian wheat and that fixed for British and Canadian wheat?

- To some extent it would. The abnormal profit over and above £3 per ton, basing freight on £5 to £11 per ton, was anything from £2 to £8 per ton. If the British Government, under their excess war-time profits tax, took 60 to SO per cent, of the increase it is clearly seen that they have received out of the freights paid to convey Australian wheat to Europe, sums amounting to from 30s. to £6 per ton.
- That was of no benefit to the Australian farmer.

- No, the British Government received an excess profit of anything from 6d. to 3s. per bushel on our wheat. The British consumer did not derive very much benefit, as a freight of £5 equals 2s. 8Jd. per bushel, and a freight of £11 equals nearly 6s. per bushel.
- Was it not more a question of expediency in regard to the transportation of the wheat?

- I am not touching that point just now. The Australian farmer admittedly sold at a low price compared with the world's parity. As I have mentioned, the British consumer did not receive very much benefit, and the freights mentioned had to be added to the price obtained by the Australian Wheat Board, f.o.b. Australia, or its wheat sold and shipped at that freight.
