Under any circumstances, even at the highest rate of freight, Australian wheat was the cheapest delivered to Great Britain at c.i.f. prices, as the New World growers obtained 9s., 10s., Ils., and 12s. per bushel for their product. The British consumer did not derive much benefit directly, but a good deal of the profits went indirectly into the British coffers as war taxation.

speech.para: Reference has been made to the Australian Government's line of steam-ships and its effect on freights. I have already mentioned that the responsibility in connexion with the loss on the Pools is not the responsibility of the Federal Government, but is clearly the responsibility of the various States. The farmer feels that he has been harshly dealt with, and according to a statement made by the Acting Prime Minister, their losses will not be paid out of the Consolidated Revenue nor out of the taxpayers' pockets as a whole. The farmers are being asked a high price for next season's cornsacks - at least 5d. per bushel. Mr. Asquith admits that the Australian farmers have contributed to the British war-time profits, and Mr. Prothero, the Minister of the Board of Agriculture, has also alluded to the patriotism of the Australian farmers. We should all face the position squarely, and do something for them.

talk.start.para: - What do you suggest? J

- I suggest, in view of the greatly increased cost of the production, the probable increase in the world's shipping during the next two or three years, and the statements made in connexion with the starving millions of Europe, that the Government should see that the Australian farmers, who have had so much bad luck in having sold war wheat at peace prices, should have a guarantee of at least 5s. per bushel at country stations for the next three years. We have come to the point when we have to realize that wheat growing is not being undertaken as extensively as previously. Instead of the Government hesitating to guarantee 4s. for the coming season - without running any risk - they should face the position, and try to make up these losses and resuscitate such an important industry. This can be done at little risk, and it will stabilize the position. It will enable the farmer to know what he is to receive as a minimum for the next three years. The Government would incur little risk, and such action would give the primary producers of Australia some security.
- Do you estimate that the receipts of the farmer have been 4s. per bushel as a result of past transactions ?
- For the four Pools?
- Yes. Does that mean 4s. net ?
- Yes, net at country stations.
- He would not pay transport fees at all ?

- No. I pointed out that 4s. net to the farmer was at the country stations, and that it was likely that the average for the whole of the four Pools would be 5s. But with the abnormal expenses deducted the net average to the farmer would not be more than 4s. during the war period.
- You did not include assets, such as iron and timber ?
- No. I have taken the Board's figures, and analyzed them as they stand.

speech.para: On the whole, I think we can support this measure, although I give it my support with some reluctance. I believe the Government are committed, and we are, therefore, in honour bound to carry out those commitments. I do not at all agree with this " Made-in-Germany " idea of State organization and control of everything. In normal times private enterprise should have full control of all commercial undertakings. I am opposed to centripetal force as we have it today, with a Minister standing on a rostrum, controlling our producers and manufacturers. I do not believe in one man controlling the affairs of others simply by pushing a button and telling them what to do, as well as exercising the power to veto. Now the war is over, I do not favour the Government going too far with these nostrums. We have all been through a difficult time, and I believe the experience of the world has been that individual enterprise, if allowed to follow reasonab'e lines, will be more successful in developing our country, and will act generally in the best interests of the producers.

talk.start.para: - Do you mean private enterprise?

- I am warning the Government against going too far in controlling everything. The Anglo-Saxon temperament will not stand it, as we are a peculiarly constituted people. I hope the Government will, as they have commenced to do by the repeal of the War Precautions Regulations, allow trade and commerce to return into fair and reasonable channels, and that they will not attempt, in this National Parliament, to obtain control over everything from Port Darwin to Cape Leeuwin, and from Cape York to Cape Otway.
- Yet the honorable senator has just recommended a guarantee by the Commonwealth Government of 5s. per bushel for the farmers' wheat.
- Yes, but only as a quid pro quo.

speech.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT. - Order ! The honorable senator's time has expired.

talk.start.para: . - Unlike the honorable senator who has just resumed his seat, I favour State control, as I believe it is a step in the right direction. Senator Pratten said that the Anglo-Saxon people would not take kindly to such control, but during the most trying period of our national history it was found necessary, and availed of even in Great Britain in connexion with almost everything. The Government seek to continue a state of affairs which held sway during the war period, and the question has been raised whether they have the constitutional power to continue such control. The Acting Attorney-General (Mr. Groom) in speaking in another place seemed to be quite satisfied that the Government have the power, and if they have it in regard to the five commodities dealt with in the Bill, they must have similar power in regard to other commodities, especially the necessaries of life. The Government therefore will be guilty of inconsistency - having exercised' control for varying periods over the five commodities mentioned - if they do not continue to regulate prices and control supplies. If the Government have not the power, I do not think that, as suggested by Senator Gardiner, the matter will be brought before the Courts. I agree with the Leader of the Opposition that, so far as the lay- man can judge, there is at least some doubt in the matter. But I am not afraid that the action of the Government in this direction will be challenged, because 1 believe there is an implied understanding of some kind. If a Labour Government were in office, and were endeavouring to secure the powers provided in this Bill, we know that the whole matter will be fought out in the highest Court of the land.
- This control benefits many of the industries affected.

- It does; that is just the point. Senator Russell, in moving the second reading of the Bill, said that the people in whose charge the Government had placed many of these important matters, while exercising that control, were looking after their own interests. That remark is true in more til an one sense.
- What I said was that the wool-growers were practically looking after and managing their own business.

- If the Government proposes to continue legislation of the kind we are discussing, it will be well not to embody so many separate and important subjects within the one measure. It has been amply demonstrated to-day that it is impossible for any individual to deliver, within the time limit, a speech fully dealing with the whole matter contained within this Bill. It has been truly stated that the. measure consists of five Bills in one.

speech.para: Having listened to two- excellent speeches on the subject of wheat, I propose to refer to that part of the Bill having relation to the sugar industry. The growing of sugar has been keenly, harshly, and unwarrantably criticised by people in the southern States. We have heard for years a cry for cheap sugar. Sugar in Australia during the past four years has been purchasable at a lower price than in any other country in the world. It was at one time claimed on behalf of Queensland, and with every justification, that the measure of protection which bad been afforded the sugar industry had been amply justified by the extent of direct settlement brought about in the north of that State; that the trade created, and the revenue maintained by the industry, had fully repaid the people of Australia for the degree of protection' granted. We can say to-day, however, that the degree of protection hitherto accorded to the Queensland sugar industry has been fully repaid to Australia's citizens during the war. Had we been dependent upon supplies from outside sources, we would have had to pay more than double the ruling rates for our sugar. People concerned in the dried fruit and jam-making industries have been among the most conspicuous in raising the cry for cheaper sugar; but they have failed to mention that their own industries are very highly protected; more highly, indeed, than the sugar industry.

talk.start.para: - They want protection as sellers, but not as buyers.

- Quite so ! The jam-makers have contended that the commodity which they manufacture comprises equal parts of fruit and sugar. It is generally admitted, however, that in a prolific fruit season considerably more than half of the jam manufactured consists of fruit. During the first year of the war, the cost of Australian sugar was kept down by price-fixing operations in the southern States. The price was maintained at a lower level than had existed in the five years prior to the outbreak of war. That was a ridiculous condition of affairs, but it was continued for twelve or fifteen months, until the Premier of Queensland (Mr. Ryan), after consultation with the Prime Minister (Mr. Hughes), introduced what is known as the famous Sugar Acquisition Act. He commandeered the Queensland sugar crop, and, under agreement with the Commonwealth Government, sold it at £18 per ton as raw sugar. There was, of course, a great outcry; but the former price of £14 a ton for the raw commodity was unwarrantably low. The people of Queensland had had every justification for seeking an advance in the quotation for raw sugar, quite apart from the circumstances arising from the outbreak of war. When the quotation was raised to £18 a ton, the sugar industry employees were working under what is known as the McNaughton award; and the raw sugar price was satisfactory. Those conditions were maintained throughout the 1916 crop operations, and into those dealing with the 1917 crop when the famous Dickson award was made. That fixed an advanced rate of wages, and the increase was not unwarranted. Eight years ago, the wages paid in the sugar industry were as low as 25s. a week.
- " And found."

- Yes. Senator Crawford was at that time president of the Sugar Producers Association. The workers had become organized, and they wrote to the secretary of the association requesting a conference for the purpose of ascertaining whether the industry could not afford to pay 5s. a day for an eight-hour day. The growers, however, refused to grant a conference. They replied that they knew what the rate of wages amounted to and what they could afford to pay. They would not grant an interview with the men.
- That is not a correct statement.
- The association refused to, meet the men in. conference, with the result that the latter were forced to go on strike. That was in 1911.
- You do not mention that a large amount of the work was done under contract, and that the men made much more than 25s.a week " and found."

- The employers, at any rate, would not discuss whether the rate should or should not be 5s. a day. The next step was taken by Mr. Tudor, as Minister for Trade and Customs, when he issued regulations providing for the payment of1s. per hour. Of course, there was another howl. The McNaughton award constituted an advance upon that rate, while the Dickson award provided a still further increase. At a selling price of £18 a ton for raw sugar it was found impossible to pay the rates set out in the Dickson award. The plea for an advance in the selling price could not be combated. About that time a conference of sugar-growers was called by the Queensland Government to ascertain what the growers considered a fair price for raw sugar at which they could pay the rates under the Dickson award. The estimate varied from £22 10s. to about £25 a ton. Senator Crawford at that time was in Melbourne with the secretary of the Australian Sugar Producers Association (Mr. Pritchard). Those gentlemen interviewed the Prime Minister (Mr. Hughes). I understand that they put a proposal before him to the effect that the sugar-growers would agree to the purchase of their crop at £22 7s. per ton for raw sugar, with a quid pro quo in the form of an assurance by Mr. Hughes that the crop for that year, namely, 1917, would be harvested by industrial operations conducted under the protection of the War Precautions Act. Mr. Hughes undertook that if any trouble occurred in Queensland the Prime Ministerwould introduce a regulation under the War Precautions Act to insure that the crop was taken off. Mr. Hughes did not indicate from what source he proposed to secure the labour. He did not mention whether it would comprise more of his Maltese importations, whether it would consist of Japanese labourers, or whether advantage would be taken of the compulsory services of men employed in home service duties. The source of that labour was known, apparently, to Mr. Hughes alone, but he gave the assurance that the Queensland crop would be taken off.
- In other words, he was protecting the people's food supplies.

- Fortunately for the people's food supplies, and for the people themselves, it did not become necessary for Mr. Hughes to fulfil his undertaking. The saner members of the Federal Cabinet must have restrained Mr. Hughes' impetuosity.
- I am not aware of Mr. Hughes having given any such assurance.
- I will convince the honorable senator of that later; but I know that that was the situation.
- In the meantime you make the assertion.
- To be proved later.

- Yes. When those representations on behalf of the Sugar Producers Association were being made, Mr.Hughes announced in the House of Representatives that the Commonwealth Government was about to- purchase the crop that year at £22 7s. per ton. The price was generally regarded as being about the minimum, and the announcement was generally well received. However, certain other influences evidently got to work, because that offer never formally reached the Queensland Government. Once the intimation had been made in the House of Representatives, manufacturing interests presumably got busy, and told Mr. Hughes his offer for the raw commodity was too high. Eventually the price was whittled down to £21, and a sort of promise was made that if anything remained over at the close of operations the margin would be divided between the sugar -growers and the manufacturers. I do not think the growers have heard anything about the division since then. That purchase price for raw sugar, as compared with the quotation for refined sugar, has had the undoubted effect of increasing the manufacturers' profits; and under this Bill Parliament is now asked to extend the term of the manufacturers' profit-making. When Mr. Hughes' offer was made to the Queensland Government it had been reduced to £21 a ton. Even then the proposition was hedged about with most outrageous stipulations. Mr. Hughes asked that the Queensland Government should undertake and guarantee that during the currency of the agreement, and with respect to succeeding crops - if the agreement were to cover them - there would be no industrial disputes.
- Was that an outrageous condition ?
- It was a preposterous proposal to ask any Government for such a guarantee.
- In a land of compulsory arbitration ?

- Presently I shall point Senator de Largie to something even more preposterous. Mr. Hughes asked the Premier of Queensland to give an undertaking either that the waterside workers would not go on strike during the currency of the agreement or that no difficulty would be experienced with them. Obviously the Queensland Premier has no jurisdiction over the waterside workers. That is a Federal matter. It was impossible for him to give any such undertaking. In my opinion, these preposterous suggestions were advanced by Mr. Hughes in accordance with his usual method of asking for so much, and allowing a bit of room to come and go upon in a spirit of compromise. When the Queensland Government was compelled to refuse his preposterous request, Mr. Hughes said: "Very well, we will meet you half way and give you this." The Premier of Queensland had then to sign the agreement, because the interests of the Queensland crop imperatively demanded it. The season was wearing on, and a press bombardment was being directed against him on account of his delay in signing the agreement, and thus fixing the price of raw sugar. Eventually, when the agreement was signed, Mr. Hughes retained what, in my opinion, he meant to retain in the first instance and no more. Here, I may be permitted to inform the Senate that when the Queensland Labour party went to the country in 1915 it did so with a proposal that Cane Prices Boards should be established for the purpose of regulat ing the price of sugar cane. That party was returned triumphantly, and during the first session of the next Parliament, it passed a measure called "An Act for the Regulation of Sugar Cane Prices." My Queensland colleagues will admit that the operation of that Statute has proved most beneficial to the sugar-growers in that State. One of the most baneful effects of the bounty system in connexion with the sugar industry was that it aimed at the production of a high tonnage irrespective of the sugar contents of the cane.
- In some localities only.

- I suppose that if we had to sell our cane by weight any one of us would naturally grow the particular species of cane that would produce the greatest tonnage. That was an evil of the bounty system. The Cane Prices Boards have encouraged the cultivation of a cane of higher density, and with a better sugar content, with the result that the cane farmer has not now to produce so high a tonnage in order to obtain the same amount of money. Thus the Act has been of mutual advantage to the grower and the miller.
- And to the consumer ?

- The consumer hardly comes in there. In addition, it is safe to say that the operation of these Boards has resulted in a. general increase to the sugar-grower of about 9s. per ton of cane. When this particular legislation was enacted at the instance of the Labour Government of Queensland, it was naturally expected that the sugar interests would welcome it. As a matter of fact, the growers did, but the millers did not. The proprietary mills were up against it immediately, and they sought to evade its provisions in every possible way. The Court records of Queensland are liberally bespattered with the prosecutions of mills, because they failed to carry out the awards, and thus sought .to defeat the will of Parliament. One of these Court cases eventually reached the Privy Council on appeal. In this particular prosecution, which originated in the Bundaberg district, the District Court Judge gave his judgment in favour of the action of the Government. The Supreme Court of Queensland upset that judgment, and its decision was in turn reversed by the full bench' of the Supreme Court of that State. The milling authorities then appealed to the High Court, which not only turned down the Act, but in doing so gave a unanimous judgment - an exceedingly rar© occurrence. Mr. Ryan then took the case to the Privy Council, which upset the decision of the High Court.
- And yet the Queensland Labour Government are endeavouring to make the High Court the final Court of appeal.

- And so it should be. I trust that in the not distant future we shall get brighter intellects on the benches of all the Courts of Australia and a few younger men. I have mentioned this matter because the proprietary mills in Queensland have endeavoured by other methods to nullify the effects of this beneficent legislation. I recollect the occasion when the Colonial Sugar Refining Company's mill refused admission to the check chemists whose services were necessary to check the density of the cane which was being operated upon. When the Government made it compulsory for the company to admit these chemists, one would naturally have thought that the difficulty was at an end. But when the price was increased to £21 per ton - that was the price which the milling interests demanded of Mr. Hughes - he, at their dictation, forced it upon the Queensland Government. When the regulation of the Sugar Cane Prices Act was amended to overcome this opposition to the Cane Prices Board, the Colonial Sugar Refining Company discovered a loop-hole by which it could evade its legal responsibilities. Honorable senators will, I think, be surprised when I show them the extent to which this monopoly is prepared to go in order to achieve its ends and to obtain an advantage for itself in spite of the law. Section 6 of the Regulation of Sugar Cane Prices Act of Queensland. 1915-17 .provides -

quote.para: A local Board may, with respect to the lands and the mill for which they have been constituted, make an award determining the price or prices to be paid md accepted by the owner or the owners of the mill and cane-growers respectively for sugar-cane sold and taken delivery of at the mill concerned, and determining all matters relating to the supply of sugar cane and payment therefor.

speech.para: One would think that the position there was most explicitly stated. It is plainly set out that sugar cane sold to the mills, and paid for, shall be subject to the operation of that Act. . But the Colonial Sugar Refining Company saw a means of evading the Statute. Section 6 provides only for the sale to the mills of sugar cane by a grower. Nobody would expect that any person but a grower would sell sugar cane to the mills. But the Colonial Sugar Refining Company either persuaded or coerced growers who supplied their mills not to sell the sugar cane direct to those mills, but to sell it to one of their staff in Sydney. Thus, John Smith purchased the cane, and sent it to their mills, with the result that the (provisions of the Act were defeated. That illustrates the depth to which high commercialism in Australia is prepared to descend. At the present time there are many districts in Queensland in which numbers of cane farmers are unable to take advantage of an Act which has been passed for their special benefit, and which is operating to such good purpose in other districts of that State. That the growers are behind the retention of the regulation of the Sugar Cane Prices Act was shown by the result of the election in 1918, when the Ryan Government were returned to power with a greater majority than ever. Under the agreement embodied in the Bill which is now before us, we are asked to continue till the 30th September a stipulation which prohibits the operation of the regulation of the Sugar Cane Prices Act in certain districts in Queensland. I shall endeavour to show how that result is brought about. Part 4 of the Bill is very brief. In fact, the whole proposal relating to the sugar industry, which, I suppose, is, roughly worth ' no less than £7,000,000 or £8,000,000 annually to Australia, consists of only one clause, containing three sub-clauses and covering about eleven lines. Clause 7 says -

quote.para: Any person who, without the consent in' writing of the Treasurer, sells, or offers for sale, at any time before the prescribed date, any sugar of the grade known as 1A, at a greater price per- pound than the prescribed price, shall be guilty of an offence.

item.para: The Governor-General may make regulations fixing the prescribed price at which sugar miiy be sold at any time before the prescribed date.

Until any regulation is made in pursuance of this section, the prescribed price of sugar of the grade known as 1A shall be threepence halfpenny per pound, plus such sum as represents the cost incurred by the vendor in respect of the delivery of the sugar to him.

speech.para: That does not appear to contain anything of a very drastic nature. But if we turn to the preamble of the measure, it will be observed that, owing to the following up of the conditions which operated during the war period, it has been found necessary, inter alia; to ratify an agreement with the State of Queensland for the acquisition by the Commonwealth of the raw sugar produced in that State during the seasons 1918 and 1919.. The preamble also covers an agreement with certain refining companies for the refining of the raw sugar so acquired. "What is that agreement? Its* ramifications are plainly set out, and if honorable senators will peruse the preamble they will see the pertinency of my remarks concerning the regulation of the Sugar Cane Prices Act. Clause 3 of the agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the Queensland Government relating to the purchase of sugar for the seasons 1918 and 1919 reads -

quote.para: The Commonwealth and the State Government mutually agree: - (a) that neither Government will until this agreement has been fully performed and the refined sugar resulting from the refining of raw sugar delivered under this agreement has been fully disposed of by the Commonwealth -
XXX. (i) take or sanction any Executive or administrative action; or

item.label: (ii)
item.para: introduce, support, assist, or encourage any proposed legislation which would have or be likely to have the effect of altering (otherwise than as set forth in this agreement) -

item.label: (i)
item.para: the conditions existing on the 14th day of May, 1918;or

item.label: (ii)
item.para: the legal rights and obligations of sugar cane growers and sugar mill owners on that date.

speech.para: The agreement expressly, forbids any legislative or Executive interference by the Queensland. Government with the conditions that existed in May, 1918. I know it has been stated repeatedly in the press, and, no doubt, I shall be told here, that that provision was inserted so as to avoid' industrial legislation varying the nature of the award during the currency of the agreement. That was the reason given to the newspapers, but the real reason was to prevent the Queensland Government from amending the Sugar. Cane Prices Board -Act, in order to compel the Colonial Sugar Refining Company's mills' to buy their cane sugar from the growers instead of through an official in the Sydney office, who thus comes in as an intermediary. The Queensland Government desired to amend their legislation in - the direction indicated, and Colonial Sugar Refining Company growers wanted an amendment, but, unfortunately, have been prevented by this agreement, which will be ratified in the Bill now under consideration, so that the Queensland Government will not be permitted to continue its sugar policy. This is wholly wrong, and honorable senators should know the real position when they are asked to agree to the proposal. We hear a great deal about the necessity for increased production, now that the war is over, but it seems strange that encouragement is not to be given to primary producers in that part of Queensland which most urgently requires development. The restrictions which have been operating for the past couple of years will continue to operate until the Commonwealth inform the Colonial Sugar Refining Company that they must treat the sugar-growers in their districts in a manner similar to the treatment accorded to growers served by other mills throughout the State.

talk.start.para: - Colonial Sugar Refining Company growers are, and always have been, treated better than those in any other part of Queensland.
- If that is so, where is the necessity for this provision in the agreement?
- They asked for it.

- If Colonial Sugar Refining Company growers are prepared to enter into an agreement with the company, it suggests, as Mr. Justice Higgins remarked in Court the other day in regard to another case, that some other influences have been at work. It may be regarded as pretty good evidence of the operation of coercive influences, and so I accept, with some reservation; any speeches made, or petitions signed, by growers in districts controlled by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company.
- Does that remark apply as well to the attitude of the seamen towards the Arbitration Court?

- Well, there may be an attempt to-day to coerce the seamen into the Arbitration Court. If the honorable senator desires to initiate, at some other time, a discussion on the present industrial dispute, I shall have no hesitation in expressing my views upon that subject-

speech.para: There is another provision in the agreement which should call for opposition from all senators who have the welfare of Australia at heart. In the first clause the following appears : -

quote.para: That in view of the large financial responsibility incurred by the Commonwealth Government under this agreement, and in order to avoid, as far as practicable, the production of raw sugar in excess of the normal requirements of Australia, the Queensland Government will not, during the said seasons of 1918-10-

item.para: Erect or assist in or encourage the erection of any new mill for the treatment of sugar cane into sugar; or
remove or assist in or encourage the removal of any sugar mill from its present site; or
alter, enlarge or extend, or assist in or encourage in the alteration, enlargement, or extension of any sugar mill so as to increase its present crushing capacity.

speech.para: Does Senator Crawford stand for that?

talk.start.para: - The Government waived that months ago.

- Then why is it being embodied in the present agreement ? It is well known and generally admitted that the trend of sugar cultivation in Queensland is northward, into the tropical regions of the State. With exception of Nambour, Bundaberg, and Childers districts, the disposition is to extend cultivation into the more northern parts of the State, where the density is higher and the ground new, and where the crops are so prolific as to treble the capacity of the mills. Senator Crawford will agree with me that mills like the Invicta, if erected in such places as the Stone River, Tully River, Daintree River, and as far north as Bloomfield River, could be worked to two or three times their present capacity.
- The Invicta mill is being removed now, or it will be removed as soon as the strike is over.

- The tendency in more settled districts is to go in for larger and more modern mills, but some mills now operating in the lower districts of the State might with advantage be removed to those northern parts of Queensland, where they would suit requirements admirably until production had so increased as to justify the erection of mills of greater capacity. Under this agreement, the Queensland Government will not be allowed to assist any such movement for the extension of the industry.
- The Invicta mill is being removed.

- But the Queensland Government are taking no hand in it.Senator Crawford will remember that the sugar-growers on the Burdekin came to the assistance of the Haughton River producers who wanted the Invicta mill. The Government of Queensland took no hand in the business financially.
- They did not want to.
- They were not allowed to.
- Do the members of the Queensland Government want to assist?

- I know the Treasurer is sympathetic towards the extension of the sugar industries in the northern part of Queensland, but, as I have said, the Queensland Government are prevented from making an advance to growers. In the face of this agreement, how can honorable senators talk of the necessity for increasing production? If they continue to do so, I shall be forced to the conclusion that they are talking with their tongues in their cheeks Senator Crawford would not go into any district in Queensland other than those served by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company and advocate the removal of the Cane Prices Board award.
- My district has never had it.

- If the award is such a good thing for other districts, it should be equally good for those districts and growers served by the Colonial Sugar Refining Company's mills; but under the agreement between the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments they will not be allowed to invoke the aid of the Act. They are obliged to sell their cane to an official in Sydney, instead of to the mills, and thus, by means of a third person, the award of the Cane Prices Board is evaded. Senator Crawford, who took a prominent part in a quiet way in endeavouring to have the sugar industry carried on under regulations of the War Precautions Act, knows all this. He is in touch with everything that is going on.

speech.para: When the selling price of raw sugar was £14 per ton, the Colonial Sugar Refining Company always had a margin of £6 per ton between the prices for raw and A1 refined, but when the price of raw sugar was raised to £18 per ton in 1915, the Colonial Sugar Refining Company advanced the price of refined sugar to £25 10s., increasing the margin by 30s. per ton. Subsequently, when the price for raw sugar was raised to £21, refined sugar became £29 5s., the margin being £8 5s. It is fair to ask what becomes of that £8 5s., which represents a margin twice as great as the margin in Europe under the Cartel system, and three times the margin allowed in America. Under the agreement which the Minister was good enough to show me, provision is made for a number of charges.

talk.start.para: - I think I can say that that has nothing to do with the fixing of the final price. It is fixed by the Government, and is based on the quantity we have to import to make up the shortage locally. We strike an average price.

- That was done in 1915. I hope that the Minister will be able to inform us later on, in addition to the charges allowed under the agreement, how the difference of £8 5s. to which I have referred is made up.

speech.para: There is one other matter to which I wish to refer. It is provided in clause 12 of the agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the Colonial Sugar Refining Company that -

quote.para: The gross proceeds of all sales by the company of all products of the raw sugar will be collected by the company, and will be chargeable with the following costs, expenses, and charges, viz. : -

item.label: (a)
item.para: the f.o.b. price of the raw sugar;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the shipping charge, provided for in clause 4 hereof; which, as I have mentioned, is 32s.11d. per ton -

item.label: (c)
item.para: the refining charge provided for in clause 5 hereof ; which is 27s. 6d. per ton -

item.label: (d)
item.para: freight insurance, wharfage, and cartage charges on and in respect of refined products shipped to Western Australia, and between the refineries ;

item.label: (e)
item.para: the actual cost of tinning and packing syrup and treacle;

item.label: (f)
item.para: the actual cost of packages in which refined sugar is contained;

item.label: (g)
item.para: the selling charge provided for in clause 7 hereof.

speech.para: The selling charge is 7s. per ton -

item.label: (h)
item.para: the interest charge (ifany), provided for in clause 8 hereof;

item.label: (i)
item.para: the managing charge 'provided for in clause 9 hereof.

speech.para: This managing charge provided for under clause 9 amounts to £1 per ton, and apparently it is imposed, on top of all the other charges which have been referred to, including the shipping charge of 32s. l1d. per ton, and the refining charge of 27s. 6d. per ton.

talk.start.para: - The managing charge is their profit.

- No doubt Senator Crawford will be able to explain why such a charge is necessary. He is in a position to enlighten the Senate on the subject. I point out that the cost of packing syrup is paid for ; the cost of the packages is paid for ; the cost of refining and shipping are paid for; and there is a selling charge of 7s. per ton; and I want to know why, on the top of all this, there should be a managing charge of £1 per ton. It does seem strange to me that when the several charges for the work performed by the company are set out in the agreement, there should also be provision made for a managing charge.

speech.para: There is a belief generally held that the Colonial Sugar Refining Company is getting far too much out of the business under the control of the Government. I believe that the consumers of Australia are not hardly dealt with when they can purchase Al refined sugar at 3½d. per lb. In normal times, quite apart from war time, the consumer would be doing fairly well in obtaining Al refined sugar at that price. But there is a section of the community that, in my opinion, is somewhat harshly dealt with, though not as harshly as were the cane-growers prior to the increased prices fixed for cane. Under the old conditions the grower had to take whatever the miller or refiner was willing to give him. Since he has had the assistance of the Cane Prices Boards his position has been improved. I do not think that the retailer of sugar is now getting quite as fair a deal as he is entitled to. I think that a little more might be taken from the Colonial Sugar Refining Company and given to the retailer.I do not swallow all the circulars that we have received from the Victorian Grocers Association and similar bodies, but, having looked into the matter, I think that the retailer is not now allowed a sufficient margin to enable him to make a fair profit from his operations in the sale of sugar. I believe that the Colonial Sugar Refining Company, as the refining monopoly, is still getting too much out of the business.

talk.start.para: - What would the honorable senator consider a fair profit for the refiner?

- I look at the balance-sheets of the Colonial Sugar Refining Company, and find that every year their profits run into hundreds of thousands of pounds. It is not a question of what I consider a fair profit, but of the profit which the company makes and distributes every six months. That is where the shoe pinches.
- It is what the company determines.

- Yes. I very much regret that when representations were being made to Mr. Hughes, -the recommendations of the combined growers of Queensland made to the Premier of that State and Mr. Lennon were not brought before him. It was said that they made a demand for £25 per ton, but I think that, on good grounds, what they asked for was £23 or £22 10s. per ton. The representations, which, presumably, were made to Mr. Hughes through some occult source, and induced him to say that he would not allow £22 7s., but only £21, per ton, were not in the best interests of the sugar-growers of Queensland.
- Whatever the increase to the consumer, we are making no profit out of the business.
- A profit was made out of the business for one or two years.
- Only in the first year.
- A profit of £500,000.
- I think that we shall lose this year, because we have to import more.
- That brings me back to my contention that there is not enough in the business for the retailer.
- I want it to be clearly understood that the loss is on importations, and not on the local product.

- That is worth knowing. In normal times we hope that, with the development of the industry, the bogy of over-production referred to in the agreement will not be regarded seriously. There have, I think, been only three years in the history of the industry in Australia in which the production, overtook the consumption. In the circumstances, when we see a statement in an agreement between two Governments suggesting a fear of over-production, it makes us a little suspicious, and inclined to think that some persons were looking for an excuse on which to base their opposition to development at the hands of the Queensland Government.

speech.para: I want some information from Senator Russell as to how the margin between the selling price of raw sugar - £21 per ton - and the selling price of refined sugar - £29 5s. per ton - is accounted for, and how it is distributed; and, also, I should like to know why the provision to which I have referred cannot be omitted from the agreement? As Senator Crawford has intimated, the provision preventing the development of sugar factories has been waived by the Government, and I can, therefore, with every justification, ask the Minister to excise it from the agreement, so that when we pass this Bill embodying the agreement we shall not be perpetuating that hindrance to the development of this very important industry in Australia.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: . - The debate on the Commercial Activities Bill presents two important features; first, the limitation of its scope, and, secondly, the limitation of speeches recently adopted by the Senate.

speech.para: It has already been discovered by those who have dealt with this subject that they were not able, within the limited time at their disposal, to fully express their opinions. The Bill gives certain powers, or assumes certain powers, to legislate in the direction of controlling dairy produce, sugar, wool, flax, and whea't. If this Parliament now has power to legislate in the direction indicated in the Bill, it has had that power all along. I understand the Government are fortified in their action in introducing this measure by the advice of certain legal gentlemen, and I believe the opinions expressed by those gentlemen are unanimous. I am not a lawyer, but I dare say that when this measure becomes law it is quite within the realms of possibility that a test case will be brought in the High Court, and that its provisions will be found, to be ultra vires. One of the legal advisers of the Government in this connexion may become a Justice of the High Court of Australia, and in that capacity may be called upon to interpret the Constitution of the Commonwealth. The constitutional aspect of this matter appeals to me.

talk.start.para: - It is a very important aspect.

- As Senator Bakhap has interjected, it is an important aspect, and it is the crux of the whole Bill. If we can legislate for a future period in connexion with any of the products mentioned in the Bill, we must have possessed the power to do so hitherto.
- We are completing contracts - that is the difference.

- I admit that. These contracts were entered into under the War Precautions Act, which will expire within a certain time by a mandate of this Parliament, but this Bill is to continue some of its provisions after the Act has expired. The War Precautions Act in itself is all-powerful. It is an absorbing and comprehensive measure, but when that awful Act dies, the extraordinary powers vested in the Government, and the contracts referred to by Senator Reid, must necessarily die with it. The War Precautions Act has been responsible for many glaring acts of maladministration, and under its protection our liberties have been suppressed. I fail to see how we can perpetuate its provisions by a- Bill such as this, which provides that the price of dairy produce, wool, sugar, flax, and wheat may be fixed until 1920. What is to prevent us fixing the price of these particular commodities for fifty years hence? I ask the Minister in charge of the Bill if be will point out to the Senate what section of the Constitution permits this Parliament to fix the price of, say, butter or sugar, and forbids Parliament fixing the price of any other commodity. Pricefixing has 'rt very important bearing on this particular Bill, and one would naturally like to know why we cannot go farther and fix the price of every commodity in general use throughout Australia. If we have the constitutional power to fix the price of butter and sugar, surely we have the power to fix the price of other articles. While the price of certain articles is to bo regulated, and the profiteer is to be held in check, he is to be allowed to run rampant in other directions. Why not fix the price of meat?
- Those who argue in favour of the measure say that no meat contracts are still in operation.
- That may be so, but, independent of any contracts entered into, we are told that we have the power to fix the prices of other articles.
- Not unless they are associated with some war arrangement. I deny that we have the right to fix the price of sugar, for instance, unless that commodity is connected with a war arrangement.

- If we are to take advantage of this measure, Parliament has the power, under the Constitution, to fix the price of anything. I believe contracts have been entered into in connexion with meat, and it is well known* that at the present time meat is very high in price.
- I saw yesterday that mutton was selling at 4d. per lb.
- I will quote the price of mutton later on.
- That is all the primary producer is receiving.

- To-day the cool stores of Australia are packed with. meat from floor to ceiling, and we are paying more for meat in Australia than is being paid for similar meat after exportation to Great Britain. The food exploiter is abroad in every way, and I shall quote one or two instances in support of my statement. Price-fixing was established during war-time by this Parliament, but no sooner had the Armistice been signed than the Price-fixing Board was abolished. High prices are still ruling, and so much so that at present we are in a state of industrial turmoil. Many charges have been made against the seamen who are endeavouring to improve their conditions of employment. As a result of their ceasing work, other industries have been held up, but I am surprised that even a greater number of workmen in Australia have not revolted against the prevailing conditions. The cost of living in Australia is so great that it is impossible for many to meet it, and I am surprised that the workmen engaged in other industries have not acted similarly. The seamen have been upbraided with not going to the Arbitration Court, but there are people in Australia who have increased the prices of butter, sugar, and other commodities without reference to any tribunal. Here is a quotation showing the profits received by the shipping companies during the war. There was no submission of their case to arbitration. The particulars are given under the heading of " Shipping Sharks. Millions Yearly from Excessive Charges. Shipping Companies' Profits."

speech.para: In connexion with the seamen's strike it is interesting to note what profits the shipping companies have made during the war period. That is in relation, of course, to their plea that they cannot concede the men's demands, and with respect to their action in raising fares and freight, in some cases, already. I have been asked more than once in this chamber to give the names and particulars of the companies. They are as follows: - Adelaide
Steamship Company - profits, 1914, £43,754; 1918, £77,504. Orient Steam Navigation Company - balance carried forward, 1916, £96,996; 1918, £115,073.

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon T Givens

talk.start.para: - Order ! How does the honorable senator connect those particulars with the Bill under discussion?
- The Measure is entitled the Commercial Activities Bill, sir.
- Its scope is very wide, but I can find no reference to shipping except incidentally-

- Except that some of these companies were engaged in the transport of wheat, and wheat is one of the matters dealt with in the Bill. My shipping information continues: - Burns, Philp, and Company - net profit, 1914, £121,053; 1918, £183,820; funds, reserve, 1914, £35,000; 1918, £75,000; reserve fund, 1914, £65,000; 1918, £225,000. Howard Smith and Company -net earnings, 1916, £184,481; 1918, £206,794; transferred to dividend funds, 1916, £184,481; 1918, £206,794; transferred to dividend funds, 1916, £4,313; 1918, £17,004. Huddart, Parker and Company - net profit, 1914. £57,000; 1918, £87,000;. dividends, 1914, £57,000; 1918, £87,000; reserve for contingencies, 1914, £30,500; 1918, £131,200. Melbourne Steamship Company - net profit, 1914, £116,000; 1918, £162,000; brought forward, 1914, £5,700; 1918, £42,000; dividend, 1914, £105,000; 1918, £155,000.

speech.para: Surely dairy produce and the price of sugar have something to do with the cost of living, I propose to quote certain figures issued by the Commonwealth Statistician. Knibbs' report for May indicates the changes which have taken place during that month in the prices of forty-six articles of foodstuffs and groceries. It appears that there has been a general increase of . 6 per cent, as compared with April of this year. In Queensland, Tasmania, and Victoria there have been small decreases, the greatest of which occurred in Victoria. In New South Wales there was an increase of 1 per cent. The South Australian increase amounted to Is. 6d. per cent. The
Western Australian increase was 11.1 per cent.

talk.start.para: - That was caused by the strike. The cattle could not be brought down.

- At the time to which I refer there was no strike. There has been a general increase of 10.2 per cent, as compared with May last year. The percentage increases are: - Western Australia, 22.8; Queensland, 16.2; New South Wales, 13.5; Victoria, 5; South Australia, 4.9; and Tasmania, 2.8. There has been a general increase of 45.7 per cent, since the outbreak of the war.

speech.para: This Bill might have gone further than it seeks to do, for while sugar and dairy produce are important factors of domestic expenditure, it must be admitted that the present industrial dispute has not been the cause of the vastly increased cost of living. Prices in practically every direction were rising by leaps and bounds, and had there been no seamen's dispute there would still have been increases. If we are to legislate in respect to commercial activities at all, we should " go the whole hog." Only one Government in the whole of Australia has endeavoured to grapple with the situation. In Queensland to-day there is a Bill before the Parliament having reference to all the domestic necessities of the people.

Why was not tobacco included within the scope of this measure? The British-Australasian Tobacco Company made the Government a free gift of £30,000 for Repatriation. The latest issue of Stead's discloses the results of two years' trading. In March, 1918, the net profits amounted to £555,315. In 1919 the net profits had risen to £561,136. Shares in subsidiary companies represented £4,769,470. The capital of that company totals £5,254,000. During the year in which it was stated that that company would have to close its doors if an increase in the price of its manufactures was not made, the concern showed a net profit of more than £561,000.

The balance-sheet of the Colonial Sugar Refining Company has just been published. The profits for the Australian company, acting only as " agents " for the Federal Government, totalled £310,681 for the year - a record in the history of the company. For the same company, trading as the Fiji and New Zealand Company, the year's profits amounted to £288,081. This latter company, although it has been in existence for less than three years, has loans and investments in other companies amounting to £1,690,724. The assets of the two concerns - up to 1916 they were trading as one - amounted to over £12,000,000. Such is Government control as exercised by the Prime Minister (Mr. Hughes) !

I wish now to refer to the banks in Australia. After all, they are behind this Government, and have been behind other Governments in financing Government concerns. The banks have been at the back of the Wool Pool and the wheat scheme. I think I shall be in order in quoting a statement relating to our private banks. It reads -

quote.para: Six banks in Australia have so increased their charges to the public that in the last two years, to go no further back, they have increased their reserves from £10,900,000 to £13,000,000 after paying all dividends on a liberal scale and all the taxes that were supposed to hit the fat man in his sorest place.

speech.para: I come now to the position of the pastoralists. The following extract is taken from a leading article in the Melbourne Age :-

quote.para: The earnings and profits of five pastoral companies in Australia during the last five years were as follow : - 1914, £871,926, as against £789,490; 1915. £765,699, as against £612,498; 1916, £863,046, as against £615,017: 1917, £1,216,417, as against £784,546; and 1918, £1,303,983, as against £822,902.

talk.start.para: - Can the honorable senator give us the figures in regard to the next five years ?

- I venture to say that during the past five years these persons have made sufficient profits to carry them safely over the next ten years. The average person in Australia has contributed largely, and is still contributing, to their huge profits.
- What will the average person contribute to their losses, df they make any, on account of the impending drought?
- They have made a profit of £3,500,000 on net earnings of £5,000,000. Surely that is a record in profiteering.
- I like to hear of everybody making money.
- Even of the profiteer who makes it at the expense of the community.
- Is not everybody in business for the purpose of profit?
- The extract continues -

quote.para: Bums, Philp, and Company is a typical Australian firm carrying goods in their vessels to the various ports, selling to the Australian people tea, rice, cream of tartar, and so on. For all these things they increased the price to the consumer, in some cases, by over 200 per cent. In the process they have made enormous profits. Their balance-sheet shows that in 1917 the net profit was £145,880, m 1919 the net profit was £204,968.

talk.start.para: - Are not these people taxed under the War-time Profits Tax Act?
- I am sorry that they are not taxed in the way that they should be.

speech.para: Their shares in other companies two years ago were £419,422; now they have invested £484,795.
I might go on quoting similar figures ad lib . then .
I come now to a comparison of the selling prices of meat at the State shops of the Ryan Government in Queensland with the selling prices at the Perth shops.

talk.start.para: - Do not forget that the Queensland Government sells only frozen meat.

- On the 1st July, at Ryan's shops, the price of the best sirloin was 6½d. per lb., at the Perth shops it was ls. 4d. Prime ribs at the Ryan shops were sold at 4½d. per lb., whereas in the Perth shops the price was lid. per lb. Chuck ribs at the Ryan shops were 3-|d. per lb., at the Perth shops they were lOd. per lb. Rump steak at the Ryan shops was 7½d. per lb., at the Perth shops it was ls. 4d. per lb. Beef steak at the Ryan shops was 5½d. per lb., at the Perth shops it was lid. per lb. Topside at the Ryan shops was 5d. per lb., at the Perth shops it was lid. ,per lb.
- Will the honorable senator tell me how he connects his remarks with the Bill which is under consideration ?

- Yes. I am dealing with the cost of living, which is intimately related to the Bill. The price of legs of mutton at the Ryan shops was 7d. per lb. ; at the Perth shops it was l0d. per lb. Shoulders of mutton at the Ryan shops were sold for 4½d. per lb.; at the Perth shops the price was 8½d. per lb. Loin chops at the Ryan shops were sold at 7d. per lb.; at the Perth shops they were1s. per lb.
- But Mr. Ryan stole his meat.
- Mr. Ryan has already answered the charge of stealing which Senator Reid has reiterated, and the Privy Council has relieved him of the odium of that charge.
- No, no. The honorable senator is referring to another case altogether. He is quite out of it.
- Let me deal now with the prices of groceries, including that of sugar. In this connexion I quote the following extract from the Melbourne Herald of the 11th August last: -

quote.para: GROCERY PRICES COMPARED
Rises Since 1914 Shown

Since . 1914 there have been substantial rises in the prices of groceries. The following table gives the average retail prices in Melbourne for July, 1914, and for June, 1919, as compiled at the office of the Commonwealth Statistician : -

talker.name: PRESIDENT, The
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon T Givens

talk.start.para: - I must ask the honorable senator not to continue in that strain. These matters are not relevant to the Bill.

- I am glad that I have finished quoting all that I intended to quote on. that subject. My object was to prove that this Bill should have included more than sugar, butter, wheat, and flax. I have endeavoured to show that all the necessaries of life are to-day at exorbitant prices, and if we are to take to ourselves the power to legislate in respect to one or two of them, we ought to take to ourselves the power to legislate in respect of all of those commodities which affect the daily lives of the people.
- Does the honorable senator contend that the articles which are the subject of control under the agreements mentioned in the Bill are at an exorbitant price in Australia at present?
- Some of them.
- Then where is the virtue of Government control ?

- If the Government are going to continue their control of sugar, why not extend that control to other commodities, and make them as cheap as sugar is to-day? Under the War Precautions Act, Ministers attempted to regulate the price of different commodities, but as soon as the Armistice was signed the profiteers were relieved of the obligations which previously rested upon them.
- Is dairy produce at an exorbitant price in Australia to-day ?

- I do not say that dairy produce is at an exorbitant price, but when the Government are attempting to exercise control over the articles enumerated in this Bill, why do they not extend that control so as to make it embrace other commodities?
- Have they really controlled the price of any of these articles ?

- Senator Mulcahy has made a most pertinent interjection. The price-fixing regulations framed by the Government under the War Precautions Act were not very good. But to a certain extent they deterred the profiteer.
- And to a certain extent they resulted in an actual raising of prices.

- Only in one or two instances. What happened in those instances, however, is as nothing compared with what has happened since the repeal of the price-fixing regulations. I come now to the question of rents. We all know that the Inter-State Commission has inquired, amongst other things, into such matters as rent, clothing, groceries, meat, &c. Kent is at the base of' the increased cost of living; and whilst this Parliament may not have the power to deal with the matters now under consideration, the State Parliaments have this authority. The Government of Victoria have appointed a Royal Commission to inquire into these matters, but I am afraid it is a case of Nero fiddling while Rome was burning. I will vote for the second reading of the measure, though I do not think it is constitutional. The Government could have introduced a more comprehensive Bill dealing generally with the cost of living, and trusted to the constitutionality of their position. It was, I think, wisely said by the honorable senator who preceded me, that if any person decided to test the constitutionality of this measure before the High Court, that tribunal would declare it to be ultra vires.
- If this Bill is constitutional, other attempts to control prices should be equally constitutional.
- That is what I am trying to point out.
- No. The question is, are we still in a state of war?
- What has that to do with the Bill ? If this is constitutional other measures are also.

- The question raised by Senator Mulcahy has been responsible for a division of opinion amongst lawyers. We do not know whether we are in a state of war or not. The very fact that the Government had to seek legal assistance before introducing the measure suggests that they are uncertain of their ground.
- They should have sought the co-operation of the State Parliaments.

- Senator Millen, when moving the second reading of the Repatriation Bill, observed that he' was travelling over an uncharted sea. The Government, in the Bill now under consideration, feeling no doubt that they were also about to set out on an uncharted sea, sought advice from certain legal gentlemen in Sydney as to whether the measure would be constitutional. Perhaps, a few months hence, a test case will be brought before the High Court, and some of those gentlemen may be found holding briefs to test the constitutionality of the Bill. Senator Bakhap has suggested that the State Governments should have been consulted. There was no need to do that, as the State Parliaments have sovereign rights in a matter like this. Mr. Ryan, the Premier of Queensland, is consulting nobody but his own Parliament, and he is bringing in a measure to deal with profiteering in every form.
- That is a different question altogether.

- It is impossible to separate the operation of this Bill from the question of profiteering. I leave the matter at this stage by repeating that I shall vote for the second reading, but hope that the Bill will be amended in Committee.

. - This measure, which deals with four articles of primary production, and one the result of manufacturing, raises three interesting questions. The first is the validity of the arrangement entered into during the war period by virtue of the war power, which might reasonably be considered as being validly projected into a period after the termination of war. I do not think any honorable senator, irrespective of party considerations, would be against the carrying out of an agreement, valid in spirit and almost certainly valid in the letter. The second question to which I refer is whether the people who are actively engaged in producing articles that come within the scope of this Bill are satisfied with the continuance of Government control. The third question, and to me one of equal interest with the other two. is whether certain features of the Bill are, by virtue of our Constitution, valid. It seems to me it cannot be clearly demonstrated that every provision of this measure deals with an agreement which can be considered as projecting its operation into a period after hostilities have legally terminated, that is to say, after the Peace Treat-" has been properly ratified. I will not deal with the agreement phase of the question at all, because I am altogether in favour of agreements being carried out. That seems to be so evidently sound that further argument is unnecessary.
- Would you reenact a bad agreement'?

- Not necessarily, but we must carry out an agreement if it is valid. For "instance, if I entered into an agreement with the honorable senator to do a certain thing, involving loss on my part, I should, nevertheless, be legally and morally bound to discharge the obligation.
- The position now is, that the Senate is asked to re-enact a certain agreement.

- It is in connexion with this re-enactment of agreements that I propose to make some remarks. Certain incongruities appear in statements made respecting the satisfaction of certain classes of Australian producers with the proposed extension of Government supervision. We have been told that it is highly desirable, in the interests of the wheat-growers, to continue this form of Government cpntrol; but certain honorable senators, speaking ostensibly, and, indeed, actually, in the interests of wheatgrowers, have pointed out the serious disabilities under which those producers labour because of the existence of Government control. The one statement is certainly not compatible with the other. We have been told that our wheat-growers have suffered because they have been paid less than the world's parity for their produce. If that is so - and that is the condition arising out of this form of control - the principle itself is operating inimically to the producers of wheat. In regard to flax, wool, and the exportable surplus of our dairy produce, there are agreements for sale to the Imperial Government; and at the risk of re-stating what I have already said, I repeat that all agreements for sale to the Imperial Government, made during the currency of the war, should be carried out for the full term of their validity, and therefore there can be no doubt as to the desirability of enumerating them in the Bill. But whether, under the Australian Constitution, the projection or extension of these agreements into a period following the ratification of peace is valid, and whether legislation with regard to these agreements is within the competency of this Legislature, is quite a different matter. In the preamble of the Bill there appears the statement that, " whereas the conditions brought about by the war are still operating." That is an assertion.. It may not be a fact. An assertion by this Parliament of the .existence of a certain condition is not in itself sufficient to make an enactment, based upon it. constitutionally valid. I do not admit that the conditions brought about by the state of war are operating in Australia.
- Very many of them are.

- Some are, and some are not. The assertion is only partially correct; and it is questionable whether legislation should be based -on general assertions which might easily be demonstrated to be only partially accurate.

speech.para: In regard to the constitutional phase of the Bill, beyond all doubt, there is every reason for grave consideration as to _ whether it is 'within the competency of this Parliament to do anything, in the way of re-enactment, after the ratification of the Peace terras. I have expressed the view that it is not within the competency of this Parliament to enact war legislation after peace has been legally arrived at, and I am not going to be inconsistent in my attitude towards this Bill. I say that anything in it that savours of a new enactment, with the intention of projecting its operation into the period after peace has been arrived at, is unconstitutional. I do not for a moment admit it is desirable that the Commonwealth Parliament should have power to legislate in this direction. I am going to object strenuously to any proposed extension of the powers of this Parliament for a long time to come, because anything that is sought to be done under this Bill can constitutionally and easily be performed with the consent of the States of the Commonwealth - a consent which I believe would readily be given if asked for.

talk.start.para: - The States promised to give us certain powers in wartime, and afterwards withdrew those promises.

- As a matter of fact, the powers of the Federal Government have been pronounced to be absolute in war time; it has been held that while a state of war existed anything could be done under the war powers of the Parliament. But I am not going to readily allow this Parliament to continue, during peace, and under the war power, legislation which we, as individual members, might think necessary. The war having ceased, the war 'power does not now exist.
- Do you forget the franchise of the Legislative Councils of the States?
- What has that to do with a matter like this?
- It has everything to do with it, because the Legislative Councils of the States do not represent the people.

-Do they not ? The honorable senator must remember that the State Parliaments are sovereign Parliaments in regard to all the powers they reserved to themselves. I think that about the only sound feature of this measure is the recapitulation of certain agreements which must be valid and which must be carried out, in so far as they refer to a certain period of time. But here is a clause which I am quite certain it is beyond the competency of this Parliament to enact. I refer to clause 7 of Part IV. of the Bill, dealing with sugar. It reads -

quote.para: Any person who, without the consent in writing of the Treasurer, sells, or offers for sale, at any time before the prescribed date, any sugar of the grade known as 1A at a greater price per pound than the prescribed price, shall be guilty of an offence.

speech.para: If I were engaged in the sale of sugar some months after the ratification of the Peace Treaty and I were summoned and found guilty of an offence, by a Court of first instance, for having sold sugar at a higher price than the prescribed price, and I had the necessary money, I should have no hesitation whatever in taking the matter to the High Court.

talk.start.para: - And the honorable senator would be sure to win his case.

- One statement made by SenatorNeedham was a truism. The Federal Government may consult eminent legal talent, all of which may eventually reach the High Court Bench or none of which may reach that Bench. But, still, a legal gentleman may pronounce an opinion which, as a High Court Judge, he would not indorse for a moment. Every one who has any knowledge of lawyers will agree that a lawyer giving an opinion and a Judge giving a decision are totally different individuals. The High Court of the Commonwealth has very properly shown itself to be very jealous of the rights of the States under the Federal Constitution. It will not read any power into the Federal Constitution merely to satisfy the desire of the Commonwealth Parliament. As the authority in the last resort, designed for that purpose, it will construe the Constitution with a proper and jealous regard for the rights of the States.

speech.para: I should like to know why the Government, instead of consulting this array of legal talent, did not communicate with the State Governments and point out to them the desirability, if it is desirable, of enacting such a measure as this. They might thus rapidly have obtained from them a consent, which they would not withhold, I feel sure, if it were clearly demonstrated that a clearing-up measure was required, because we still are, technically, in a state of war, and that this state subsists between the time of the declaration of peace and the ratification of the Peace Treaty.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator should not forget that there have been several conferences with State Premiers and Ministers which have been more or less futile.

- The State Premiers are not fools. Many of them gravitate eventually to the Federal Parliament and members of the State Parliaments also find their way here. If they object to a wholesale enactment which very greatly enlarges the functions of this Parliament, in all probability, it is because the proposed extension of those functions should be objected to.

speech.para: In order to be consistent - although consistency is not in itself such a great virtue, as some people assume it to be; and I give it its full value - I say that I do not view with anything but misgiving these constant endeavours to trench upon the constitutional powers of the States. What may have been good medicine for the nation during the war period should not be made its daily bread after peace has arrived. It does not at all follow that because a thing is necessary in time of war it is necessary in time of peace. We agreed under the War Precautions Act, by virtue of the war power of the Commonwealth Parliament, to practically suspend the Habeas Corpus Act. ' Every one is aware of the decision of the High Court. Judges to the effect that the Minister concerned might arrest and intern any one without giving any reason for his action. If that was not a practical suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act I want to know what would be so regarded. But no one will contend that in time of peace the Habeas Corpus Act should be suspended. .1 should be very sorry, as one who has profited by the tradition of British liberty, and who is here by virtue of that glorious tradition, to consent to the suspension of the Habeas Corpus Act in time of peace.

Because we consented, for instance, to the price of sugar being fixed in time of war, it does not at all follow that we should consent to the projection of that power to fix the price of sugar, by a possible straining of the powers of this Parliament, into a time of peace. As honorable senators are aware, I objected very voluminously - I do not know with what effect, or with what degree of legal force, though I believe that, if the matter were tried, the position I took up would be held to be legally sound - to the projection of the War Precautions Act into a time of peace. I held that to be constitutionally invalid, and I believe that any attempt to do anything of the sort in this measure will also be invalid as being beyond our competency.
The recapitulation of the agreements in this, measure, although perhaps not unnecessary, do not add to their validity. If they are valid agreements they are Valid without inclusion in this measure.

It is an exceptionally precarious position for this Legislature to take up, that it is competent for it to extend into a period of peace agreements which were of admitted validity during the time of war. I do not care if every lawyer in the Commonwealth has said it can be done, I have still my doubts whether the High Court Bench would give a similar decision.

Senator Needham took up a most remarkable position. He wanted to know why, if by virtue of the war power government control had been established over the commodities enumerated in this Bill, the whole gamut of national activity should not be within the scope of this measure. He denounced the exorbitant prices of commodities of prime necessity, yet the honorable senator could not point out that any of the articles mentioned in this Bill were being sold at an exorbitant price. If dairy produce is being sold at an exorbitant price in Australia, that, in the circumstances, does not exhibit the virtue of government control. If wheat is being sold at prices unsatisfactory to the wheat producers of Australia that does not indicate virtue in government control. If sugar is being forcibly sold, so to speak, by virtue of this agreement at prices which constrain the sugar producers in Queensland to accept half the price which sugar is bringing in the outside world, it is questionable whether that is a good thing for the sugar producers of Queensland. I represent a State in which sugar is not produced. The people of Tasmania would like to be able to obtain sugar very cheaply, because it is necessary for the manufacture of jam, which is made from the small fruits, of which Tasmania is prolific. But, speaking as a member of the Senate, I do not hope for high prices for Tasmanian products and low prices for the products of Queensland. If the sugar producers of Queensland could get twice what they are getting for sugar now, I believe they would be entitled to do so. If they are constrained, at the present moment to sell sugar at a price which represents only 60 per cent, of the price obtained for uncontrolled sugar in other parts of the world, that would appear to be a bad thing for them. If, at the present time, they are satisfied to sell their sugar at a reduction of 40 per cent, on the world'6 prices, because at times they secure from the Australian Government, by, virtue of certain arrangements, a price for sugar a little higher than the world's price in normal times, that is their own business. But it does not at all follow that an agreement of this kind is a good thing for them. I should like to hear one of the representatives of the sugar industry in the Senate tell us that the sugar producers of Queensland are altogether in favour of this arrangement, and of its continuation.

Such an agreement, valid under the exercise of the war power by this Parliament and by the Federal Government, must be carried out; but any projection of it into a period beyond the ratification of the Peace Treaty should not be attempted by this Parliament unless the sugar producers of Queensland are satisfied with the proposed arrangement.

talk.start.para: - They agreed to an arrangement to last for two years.
- After the two years' period has expired, will they like to see the arrangement continued ?
- That is a matter for consideration.

- Just so; and any projection of the agreement beyond that period is a matter for consideration by this Parliament. In other words, agreements that are valid remain valid still, but any attempt to extend their validity into a period beyond the ratification of the Peace Treaty, unless it arises out of an arrangement entered into during the period- of the war, is, to my mind, invalid.

speech.para: I am not going to say that I entirely agree with this measure. I am not at all satisfied that Government control has been a good thing in Australia. Senator Needham was very verbose about the splendid deeds that have been performed by a certain Government in respect to the price of meat. I remember that I telegraphed from Tasmania to the Prime Minister and to Mr. Massy Greene, who was at the time Minister for Price Fixing, to the effect that their performance in regard] to the fixing of the price of meat had aroused the derision and contempt of every one in Tasmania. My butcher was charging me ls. per lb. for rump steak, as good as could be obtained anywhere, and yet, when the price was fixed, he was able to charge me ls. 3d. per lb. A measure intended to prevent any increase in the price of a commodity permitted him to charge me ls. 3d. per lb. I do not like this price-fixing business.

talk.start.para: - Not after that experience.

- My experience of it is that it tends to check the production of commodities. We passed a measure here called the War-time Profits Bill. I am glad to say that I washed my hands of it, because a more pernicious measure in regard to the activities of Australia was never enacted. As a result of it, industries were strangled in their infancy by the dozen. I venture to say that if we had put out of our mind all thought of the £1,000,000 or the £2,000,000 of revenue that it was expected we should get under the operation of that measure, we would have derived ten times more benefit from the enterprise of the Australian people in establishing new industries regarding which they had to go cap in hand to the Treasurer.

speech.para: I like not this business. Beyond the fact that I believe that a man's word should be his word; that the word of a Parliament should be its word; and that any body of producers should adhere to their agreements, I do not see any virtue in this Bill. I believe that, in some respects, it is not constitutional. I believe it to be a straining of the powers of this Parliament. I do not want any straining of the powers of this Parliament. It has many functions constitutionally conferred upon it which it has not yet exercised, and which provide an ample field for its activity, and. any trespassing upon State rights, to me as a Federalist, is abhorrent.

talk.start.para: . - I intend to support this measure, simply because it is to validate certain contracts entered into by the Commonwealth Government. During the course of the debate I have noticed that frequent references have been made to the War Precautions Act, and honorable senators have blown hot and blown cold concerning its provisions. That Act has come in for a great deal of severe criticism throughout the Commonwealth, but when it is a question of perpetuating certain of its provisions there is a general desire on the part of such critics to welcome the perpetuation, if not an extension, of its provisions.
- There is a difference between an Act of Parliament and regulations under the War Precautions Act.
