- One follows the other; one is the parent and the other is the offspring. I am not in a position to offer any legal opinion on the constitutionality of the Bill, but, viewing it as an ordinary layman, with ordinary intelligence, I do not see how the contracts in question can be successfully carried out unless this Bill is passed, and the Commonwealth Government possess the authority to see that their side of the bargain is fulfilled. Supposing .Senator Bakhap's opinion holds good, and, immediately the Peace Treaty is ratified, the supreme authority of the Commonwealth ceases. If that is so, I am afraid that common sense will not influence a decision of the Supreme Court, if it will come to a similar conclusion. It is impracticable to immediately terminate contracts that have been entered into for war purposes, and it is unreasonable to say that these contracts shall cease to operate when the Peace treaty is ratified. The contracting parties must have some security, mid neither side wishes to be guilty of dishonorable repudiation. There is a vast difference between the Government retaining the power to complete contracts and stepping in with a policy of price-fixing of certain commodities. If the Government have the power to fix the price of, say, sugar, they ought to have the power to fix the price of any other commodities, such as boots, clothes and other necessaries of life. While we may consider it a very useful and necessary measure under present circumstances, there is great doubt as to its constitutionality; but I am not going to withhold my support on that account.

speech.para: Frequent reference has- been made to the cost of living and the limited powers contained in this measure. Whenever an outcry has arisen in connexion with high prices, I have endeavoured to discover the pros and cons of it, and have come to the conclusion that a good deal has been said that is really unwarranted. In this country at present the cost of living, within certain limitations, is a grievance, but it is not nearly so severe as it is in other countries, and particularly those which have been at war. We realize that the cost of certain commodities is far beyond what the cost of production warrants. Boot leather, woollen goods, grindery, and other raw materials produced in this country have been at a high price, but, as far as other commodities are concerned, I believe the rates charged are entirely beyond the power of any authority in the Commonwealth to either control or reduce. In proof of that, I may mention that in the Western State, in the early stages of the war, the cost of living aroused such, public comment that the Government yielded to the outcry to regulate the cost of living, and appointed a Royal Commission to make inquiries as a preliminary step. That Commission went about its work, and endeavoured to elucidate certain points, but came to the conclusion that there was nothing to discover at that particular time. The result was that the Commission fizzled out, was never resurrected, and no concerted effort was ever made to resurrect it or discover the cause of its abolition. The Australian Labour party was strongly represented on the Commission, but it ended in a fiasco, and has not reported even to this day for the reason stated.

Our Queensland friends will realize that while this Bill cannot regulate the cost of living, the Queensland Government, as referred to to-night, in their laudable efforts to settle the question, will never do so effectively until the Commonwealth Government are armed with the necessary powers. They may as well try to fix the price of commodities in a Melbourne or Sydney suburb at the same rates and expect the whole city area to benefit. The suburb stands in the same relation to a city as a State does to the Commonwealth. The only effective dealing with the cost of living throughout the Commonwealth is by giving the powers required to this Parliament, and making it act through its recognised organ, the Executive Government.

It is worth recalling, in connexion with the wheat question, that no effort has been made to fix the price of wheat. I wish the price had been fixed There is no reason why one commodity produced in Australia should have the advantage of a fixed fair price while others are not treated likewise. The wheat-growers are mute and docile producers.

talk.start.para: - They are sweated.

- I believe I am right in saying they are sweated more than any other section of the community. As one who has watched the work of the Wheat Pool, since its inception by the Labour party, I am pleased to say that the work of this Pool has materially improved the position of the wheat producers. Before the Wheat Pool came into existence, and when the farmers were subjected to the tender mercies of the men who entered into honorable understandings, the farmer had to sell in the open market at something in the neighbourhood of 2s. 8d. to 2s. l0d. per bushel. Papers circulated in this State made that announcement, and many of us can recall our own experiences. I am pleased to say that since the inception of the Pool, the farmers have obtained a much better price than would have been the case had they been dealing with private firms.

speech.para: Reference has been made to the ravages of mice, and I am sorry Senator Pratten is not here while I am dealing with that phase of the question. When the Government entered into an agreement with the contracting firms to handle, store, and ship the wheat, it should have been distinctly understood that the firms were to deliver the wheat in good condition.

If there be any deficit - we have heard that about 1,000,000 bushels have disappeared mysteriously - these firms, by virtue of the agreement, entered into by the several State Governments and indorsed by the Australian Wheat Board, should be compelled to hand over the full quantity, as they were morally and legally responsible for the deficit. In the Western State, when the wheat was being destroyed by mice, it was the chief concern of the firms handling it to try to escape their obligations under the agreement, 'which made them responsible for damage by mice. If the agreement entered into with those firms by the four wheat-producing States is strictly adhered to and rightly interpreted, they should return every bushel received. I do not see why the Commonwealth Government or the farmers should be responsible for the loss. If the firms are not prepared to insure the grain against damage, that is their business and not that of the farmers.

Like the previous speaker, I think we shall have to look into the question of the sugar agreement and that of price-fixing very carefully. It is only in the case of happenings of an abnormal character that price-fixing is warranted at all. The rates charged here are not the result of anything that has happened in this country. The prices charged for articles produced beyond the Commonwealth have increased from 100 to 300 per cent. and it was a case of either buying them at the high price or not purchasing at all. Many of these articles were used in the manufacture of other articles, and their high cost was reflected in the price of those other articles. I had occasion when last in Western Australia to price ordinary working shirts, and was informed that they were being sold at 7s. l1d. I had one of those shirts. I saw some which were worn out within a fortnight. I took them to the leading draper in Perth, from whom they had been purchased, and I asked what he meant by sending out such material at such a figure. He called for the head of the department concerned, and in my presence asked for an explanation. That individual stated that the shirts had been purchased from a Manchester house at a little over 7s. each, and that the Perth firm's profit was only a matter of pence per shirt. The head of the department added that exactly similar shirts had been sold prior to the war at 2s. lOd. each, and that the firm had made a greater profit upon them while selling at that price than in selling to me at 7s. lid. each. Similar evidence was tendered by the same representative of that Perth firm before the Price-Fixing Commission, which did not complete its labours. I mention that to show that my facts are undoubtedly correct. I have referred to this matter also to demonstrate that a number of articles which constitute the necessaries of life have been purchased outside Australia, and also that material bought outside Australia has commanded prices beyond the power of any authority within Australia to regulate. When we talk of the increased cost of living, we should remember that we have been, and are still, suffering from the inevitable consequences of warfare. We in Australia do not know what war is, so far as the increased prices of all things that we eat and drink and wear are concerned.

A good deal was said by Senator Gardiner about the conveyance of wheat. His remarks were to the effect that the ships purchased by the Commonwealth Government should have been employed in the carriage of the farmers' wheat on terms lower than the freight rates of other ships plying in competition. Senator Gardiner must be aware that those Commonwealth vessels came under the automatic supervision of the Comptroller of Shipping in England. There are fixed rates of freight for given distances, all round the world. The Commonwealth shipping authorities are bound to comply with those conditions. I would like to be informed by Senator Gardiner how he would propose to run the Commonwealth Steamship Line if he intended to charge lower freight rates than shipping firms in competition with the Commonwealth craft. I understand that the Commonwealth ships did not carry more than a fractional portion of the wheat exported from Australia. It would .be hard to justify our action in providing the Australian farmer only with the benefits accruing from lower freight charges in respect to our vessels. Those ships would be carrying our wheat one way, and bringing back overseas merchandise to Australia. Among that merchandise there would be, for example, mining machinery. Who will say that mining in this country is not entitled to all possible encouragement? As the result of the lack of cyanide in Western Australia, the mines on the Golden Mile were at one stage in a precarious position. Are those mines to receive no consideration in the matter of back-loading, after our vessels have conveyed Australian wheat at reduced freights to England? Why should the Commonwealth ships be called on, except for the purpose of keeping freights and fares in check, to run at much lower freight rates than the ships of other companies and countries?

talk.start.para: - Look at the profits of the private shipping companies, and you will realize that they have been the greatest profiteers throughout the war.

- Although I want to see a fair thing done by the farmers, I do not wish it brought about in a manner wholly impracticable. I shall be looking for Senator Gardiner's support when I ask the Senate to place the wheat industry in Australia on a better footing than hitherto. But, in regard to freight, I do not see how it will be practicable for the farmers to receive special advantages in the overseas carriage of their wheat while other producers in Australia do not receive proportionate benefits in relation to the return freight rates of Commonwealth vessels.

speech.para: With respect to Queensland, and to the high cost of living there, I have been pleased to note how prices were kept low for so long a period. As the war developed, however, I noted that in that State prices constantly and monotonously increased, until at last the cost of living has become higher than in any of the other States. Why is that so? The Government of Queensland to-day are in the unique position that if they really desired to stem the continuous rise in the cost of commodities they can do so, despite the activities of the Commonwealth Government. By an enactment of the Kidston Government, power was placed with the dominant party in Queensland to carry through the Legislative Council any measure which that party deemed to be in the public interest. The question may be naturally asked, why the dominant party in Queensland has not set an example to the other States?

talk.start.para: - It was doing so until 1917, when the result of the elections was to give Mr. Hughes a majority, so that he was able to pass a "War Precautions Act and regulations, which took all power from the Queensland Government, and up went the cost of living.
- That could not prevent the State Parliament from passing a law of its own, and dealing with the price of living independently.

- I am glad that Senator Ferricks has provided me with the explanation; but it is an unfortunate one. The true position is this: When the relative powers of the Federal and State Arbitration Courts were called into question, and the High Court was appealed to, the latter held that the State tribunals could concurrently fix rates and conditions of labour, always provided that they did not fix a lower rate than that fixed by the Commonwealth. With respect to the cost of living, the true, legal, and constitutional position is that, though the Federal authority may fix prices at a certain m'aximum, it is still competent for the State authority to step in, and, if it thinks that a lower figure can be reasonably set for 'the same necessary articles of living, it may take action, and that power of action will stand unchallengeable. I secured that opinion from one of the highest legal authorities in Australia; and it has fortified my contention that if the cost of living is really a grievance in Queensland - and it inevitably must be, seeing that increases have been greater there than in any of the other States - the

speech.para: Queensland Labour Government could have used their undoubted powers to fix the cost of living to their own liking.

talk.start.para: - They were getting on splendidly until the War Precautions Act took the power out of their hands.

- The other States are in no such unique and happy position as is Queensland, for they have their Legislative Councils to contend with, and those bodies can exercise the final veto upon legislative matters, and are virtually dictators. In Queensland, however, the dominant party in the Lower House can put through any measure which it sets its mind upon, in the interest of the public, despite the views of the Legislative Council. What is exercising my mind, therefore, is to discover a good reason why the Queensland Government have not set an example to the remainder of Australia by dealing with the cost of living in an effective manner, seeing that they have the undoubted power despite anything which Mr. Hughes may have done, or may be in a position tq do.
- Despite the War Precautions Act and its regulations?

- I am merely tendering the advice that Mr. Ryan has the power of action, and that he may set it moving to-morrow, and that he has had such power for the past four years; and, further, that he has left that power remain dormant while prices have soared above those in any of the other States. If is for Queensland to sweep its own front doorstep before it sets out to criticise the state of affairs in front of the doors of the other States or the Commonwealth.

speech.para: Now a word or two as to fixing prices in any way which will be likely to exercise a material effect upon the cost of living. My own view is that we shall have to treat this question very warily. Taking it all in all I do not believe it is practicable to fix prices in any way that will give general satisfaction. Let us follow the admirable example set by the British Government, which has just passed a Bill through the House of Commons with a view to preventing profiteering. I believe such power can be more successfully employed as a measure to frighten than a measure to operate. In certain instances I have no doubt that effective action can be taken. But as for enacting any measure which will prove practicable in operation over a wide range of circumstances, and that will satisfactorily influence prices, I say that any attempt in that direction will be extreme folly. The thing- has been tried over and over again, and has always been tried in vain.

There are only four industries mentioned in this Bill, and in respect of two of them it is proposed to fix prices. Other industries are left out in the cold. It is on behalf of these other industries that I intend to raise my voice in this Chamber later on. We cannot insure fair play all round if we single out a couple of industries for special treatment. When we adopt that course we must necessarily impose a handicap upon other industries. Take, for example, the sugar industry, the coal industry, and the carrying industry. Senator Ferricks told us this afternoon that the price of sugar had automatically and progressively increased from £14 per ton to £21 per ton. Who is paying that increased price? The taxpayers of this country. That expenditure has been the means of bringing under cultivation some of the richest lands in the Commonwealth. But it must be borne in mind that those who are engaged in cereal growing have to earn their livelihood upon the poorer lands of the Commonwealth, and as Henry Lawson says,. " Their struggle with the elements is everlasting war." While the sugar industry, the coal industry,, the maritime carrying industry, and other allied and secondary industries are singled out for special treatment in- the way of having the prices of their commodities fixed,, and conditions imposed, of an advantageous character, other industries are left alone or seriously handicapped. Let me cite my own case as an example.. Twenty-five years ago I was going to sea. I worked on. this coast for £7f per month. Very much less work than I did then is being done- to-day for double that amount. In other respects the conditions- of the seamen have vastly improved. What hae- happened in other industries? What is the position of the miner in. North Queensland, or "Western Australia, or Southern Tasmania? It can be said with absolute truth that he is not one whit better off than he was twenty-five years ago, whereas the position of the men engaged in the industries I have referred to has been improved beyond measure.

talk.start.para: - The metalliferous miner in New South Wales is much better off than he was twenty-five years ago.

- I would like to know how he is better off. What is wanted in this country is a Bill which will enable the scales of justice to be held more evenly as between our various industries. There is a constant tendency to foster and coddle - indeed, to convert into things of a parasitic nature - certain industries at the expense of other industries which support a very much larger population. If that be progress, it is progress in a circle. If we want real progress the scales of equity will require to be poised more evenly between all our industries. Favour should be given to none, but a fair field to all. Take the case of the coal miners in New South Wales. Are not they vastly better off to-day than they were years ago, whereas the gold miner in the Golden Mile is not nearly in as good a position as he was twenty-five years ago. Such a condition of affairs cannot, by any stretch of the imagination, be described as progress. Certain industries are advantaged beyond reason at the expense of other industries which are impoverished. I shall return to this subject at a later stage, and in the meantime shall content myself with saying that to grant particular industries most favoured conditions whilst compelling other- industries to hawk their products on the markets of the world and there to take what is offered and not what is fixed is not playing the fair game. My. voice will, therefore, be raised in the future in the direction of seeing that no more favoritism is extended to certain industries, because such treatment inevitably means the impoverishment of other industries and the inevitable injuring of general prosperity.

debate.para: Influenza Outbreak in Tasmania - Postal Facilities in Southern Tasmania.

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: - Can the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator Russell) make a statement in reply to the question which I put to him to-day ?

.- I desire to direct attention to what I regard as a policy of mistaken economy on the part of the Postal Department. I have frequently had to appeal against various efforts by that Department to save money, but the latest incident which has come under my notice relates to the curtailment of postal facilities to a considerable number of persons in the southern portion of Tasmania. The particular places to which I refer are Woodstock and Craddock. These centres are on the way from Hobart to Cygnet, and although the mail motor passes these offices twice a day, their postal services have been curtailed to one mail daily. The schools in these districts have a regular attendance of from forty-five to fifty pupils. That, of course, is a very important matter. At Craddock there are always from 130 to 140 votes recorded, showing that there are that number of adults resident in the district. Seeing that the cost of these mail services to the Department must be very small indeed, consideration ought certainly be extended to that number of people. In criticising the position my correspondent advances the argument that the only saving which can possibly be effected by the reduction of the mail service hitherto in existence will be represented by the cost of the string and sealing-wax by which the mail bags are secured once a day. I direct the attention of the Government to this matter because I believe that the policy which they are adopting is a wrong one. One of the main problems with which they are confronted is the decentralization of population. Our mail services are a very important factor in inducing people to settle in: large centres of population. In our larger cities, for example, there are three mail deliveries daily, whereas country residents, who have to suffer many disabilities, receive only one delivery. If this matter be brought before the Postmaster-General, and Ministers stress the importance of making life as agreeable as possible to the residents of our rural areas, I feel sure that the Postmaster-General will recognise the justice of what I have said.

speech.para: SenatorRUSSELL (Victoria - Vice-President of the Executive Council and Acting Minister for Defence) [9.58]. - In reply to the inquiry by Senator Keating regarding the outbreak of influenza from Tasmania, I have received the following statement from the Comptroller- General of Customs, who is closely connected with the Quarantine Department : -

quote.para: The presence of influenza in Tasmania having been officially notified by the Tasmanian health authorities, a proclamation was passed at the Executive Council on 20th August declaring the State of Tasmania to be infected with influenza. The Government of Tasmania has been informed that the Commonwealth Government now intends to assume control of the Inter-State traffic between Tasmania and the Commonwealth, and correspondence is proceeding with the view of the date being fixed on which detention of passengers in quarantine will cease. The restrictions on passengers from Tasmania will then be limited to medical inspection and travelling under permit, and on the arrival of passengers in another State they will be subject to quarantine surveillance for three days. From reports received, it appears that influenza is prevalent in all parts of the State, and that several deaths have occurred.

speech.para: In reply to the request of Senator Earle, I will have his remarks brought under the notice of the Postmaster-General, and hope to be able to furnish him with a reply in the course of a few days.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
